dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENCE. THE DESERT seen from the air. An ocean of dunes mile after mile. The late sun turns the sand every colour crimson to black and makes the dunes look like bodies pre against each other. An old AEROPLANE is flying over the Sahara. Its shadow sw over the contours of sand. A woman's voice begins to sing - Szerelem, szerelem, she in a haunting lament for her loved one. INSIDE the aeroplane are two figures. One, A WOMAN, seems asleep. Her pale head rests against the side of the cockp Behind her THE PILOT, a man, wears goggles and a leather helmet. He is singing, too, but we can’t hear him or the or anything save the singer’s plaintive voice. The plane shudders over a ridge. Beneath it A SUDDEN CLUS MEN AND MACHINES, camouflage nets draped over the sprawl gasoline tanks and armoured vehicles. An OFFICER, GERMAN, focusses his field glasses. The glasses pick out the MARK on the plane. They are in English. An ANTI-AIRCRAFT GUN s furiously. Shocking bursts of GUNFIRE. Explosions rock the plane, wh lurches violently. The fuel tank is punctured. It sprays gasoline, then erupts in flame engulfing both figures in fireball.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN. ITALY 1944. BEFORE DAWN
dialogues.text: AN ALLIED HOSPITAL TRAIN ploughs through the night carryi MILITARY WOUNDED back to Naples. A young French-Canadian nurse, Hana, walks through a long carriage past rows of the injured. She stops at the bunk WOUNDED SOLDIER. Hana bends to the boy. He’s had shrapnel his legs and cheek. She speaks softly to him.

dialogues.speaker: BANA
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Your leg will be fine. A lot of shrapnel came out - I saved you the pieces.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: You‘re the prettiest girl I've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (she hears this every day) I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Would you kiss me?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: No, I‘1l get you some tea.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (innocent) It would mean such a lot to me.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: {tender, believing him) Would it? She kisses him, very softly, on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Thank you. He closes his eyes. Hana smiles, continues along the compartment. TEASING VOICES CALL OUT after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse - I can‘t sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you kiss me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You’re so pretty!

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (good-naturedly waving away their joke) Very funny. Go to sleep now. She opens the door of the next carriage and walks straigh the carnage left by an emergency operation. MARY, another nurse, is removing a blood-soaked bundle from the operati table. Mary grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don’t ask.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DESERT. DAY
dialogues.text: THE PILOT HAS BEEN RESCUED BY BEDOUIN TRIBESMEN. Behind t the wreckage of the plane, still smoking, the Arabs picki over it. A SILVER THIMBLE glints in the sun, is retrieved Another man comes across A LARGE LEATHER-BOUND BOOK and it over to where the Pilot is being tended to. The Book i of letters and cards and paintings. They’re scattering everywhere. The Pilot is terribly burned, barely alive, h face charred. One of the Bedouins covers his face with a makeshift mask made from plaited palm leaves.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DESERT. DUSK
dialogues.text: The Pilot is being carried across the desert. The mask co his face. His view of the world is through the slats of p glimpses camels, fierce low sun, the men who carry him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. EMERGENCY FIELD HOSPITAL, 1944. LATE DAY
dialogues.text: The EMERGENCY FIELD HOSPITAL is a cluster of tents practi ahead of the Front Line. SPORADIC GUNFIRE, increasingly n sounds throughout. It’s 1944 and the war in Italy is stil intense.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAIN TRIAGE TENT. EMERGENCY FIELD HOSPITAL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Hana and her best friend, JAN, walk through the main TRIA TENT. It’s packed with the ruined bodies of the injured, swaddied in bloody bandages.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRIAGE TENT, EMERGENCY FIELD HOSPITAL. EVENING
dialogues.text: HANA IS GIVING BLOOD. She lies in a cot, next to JAN. The shelling sounds closer. Behind a curtain, OLIVER, a Doctor, is working on the mos recent patient, a young CANADIAN SOLDIER who is criticall - the tubes hanging above him, of plasma and of blood, hi stomach a bloody mess. The curtain drawn around him is pu back to reveal the two nurses in background. The Soldier just see them. He’s going to die any minute.

dialogues.speaker: CANADIAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (whispering to Oliver) Is there anybody from Picton?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Picton? I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CANADIAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: I'd like to see somebody from home before I go. Hana can only really hear Oliver’s end of this conversati but the mention of Picton chills her, and she knows, now, later, that her lover is dead.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (to Oliver) Why Picton?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He's from there - edge of Lake Ontario, right, Soldier? The boy nods.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (innocent) Hey, that’s where your sweetie’s from? Somewhere near there, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (to Oliver) Ask him what company he’s with? Oliver leans over, then turns to Hana.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Third Canadian Fusiliers.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Does he know a Captain McGann? The boy hears this, whispers to Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: CANADIAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: He bought it. Yesterday. Shot to bits. The shells are getting closer.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: (can't look at her) Doesn't know him. A SHELL suddenly lands on top of the site, perhaps fifty from the tent. THE LIGHTS GO OUT. Then ANOTHER lands. Everybody is on the floor, struggling to get on a helmet. Hana lies down, the blood still leaving her, her helmet o Oliver is next to her in the mud. Her heart is breaking.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: He’s gone, he’s gone, he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No. He’s = no.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Oh God. Oh God. The shells pound them, incredibly loud, drowning out her but each explosion illuminates it for a moment. EXT. AN OASIS. NIGHT. The SOUND OF GLASS, of tiny chimes. A music of glass. AN ARAB HEAD floats in darkness, shimmering from the ligh fire. The image develops to reveal a man carrying a large wooden yoke from which hang DOZENS OF SMALL GLASS BOTTLES different lengths of string and wire. He could be an ange The man approaches the litter which carries The Pilot. He still in the protective palm mask, wrapped in blankets. T MERCHANT DOCTOR stands over the burned body and sinks sti either side of him deep into the sand, then moves away, f the yoke, which balances in the support of the two crutch Then he slowly sets about peeling away the layers of oile cloth which protect the Pilot’s flesh. The Merchant Doctor crouches in front of the curtain of bottles, then leans back to pluck, hardly looking, certai bottles which he uncorks and mixes. He uses this green-bl paste to anoint the burned skin. All the while he is humm and chanting. The bottles continue to jingle.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACH FRONT, ITALY. LATE 1944. DAY
dialogues.text: Wounded Soldiers walk with nurses along the beach

dialogues.speaker: THIS CONVALESCENCE HOSPITAL HAS BEEN FASHIONED FROM A LON
dialogues.text: OF BATHING CABINS ON THE COAST, complete with Campari Umb and metal tables, at which are seated the bandaged and th dying and the comatose, staring out to sea or in slow, mu conversation. A BRITISH OFFICER makes notes. He is talkin wounded PATIENT, whom we recognize as the burned Pilot.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER, (0/S)
dialogues.text: Name? Rank? Serial number?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT, (0/S)
dialogues.text: No. Sorry. I think I was a pilot. I was found near the wreckage of a plane at the beginning of the war. Hana walks up to The Patient's cabin. He is propped up wi view of the sea, which is interrupted by the British Offi Hana has a blanket and a chart for The Patient‘s bed. She busies herself.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Can you remember where you were born?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Am I being interrogated? You should be trying to trick me. Or make me speak German, which I can, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Why? Are you German?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: How do you know you’re not German if you don’t remember anything?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Might I have a sip of water? Hana pours hima glass of water. He notices her.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Thank you. (he sips) I remember lots of things. I remember a garden, plunging down to the sea - nothing between you and France.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: This was your garden?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Or my wife's.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Then you were married?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I think so. Although I believe that to be true of a number of Germans. Look - (makes a small gap with his fingers) I have this much lung...the rest of my organs are packing up - what could it possibly matter if I were Tutankhamen? I’m a bit of toast, my friend - butter me and slip a poached egg on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CONVOY OF TWENTY TRUCKS - Red Cross vehicles and some s vehicles - snakes along a bumpy hill road. The war in Ita largely over and the Allies are moving up the country, th wounded and supply lines slowly following.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ITALIAN HILL ROAD. DAY
dialogues.text: A JEEP pulls out of the line and approaches the Red Cross containing Hana and The Patient. The horn blows and Hana out to see it contains her friend JAN. TWO YOUNG SOLDIERS up front, one driving, both grinning. Jan signals for Han attention.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Hana! Hana! Hana! There’s meant to be lace in the next village - the boys are going to take me. (mischievously) You don’t have any money, do you? Just in case there’s silk.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Hana, I know you do. Come on. Oh, come on. (to the soldiers) She's a softy, she loves me. Hana leans under the tarpaulin, holding some DOLLARS. The hands - hers and Jan’s - reach for each other as the vehi bump along side by side. They laugh at the effort. Jan‘s BRACELET catches the sun and glints.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (getting the money) I love you. The Jeep accelerates away. Hana sighs to the Patient. Suddenly AN EXPLOSION shatters the calm as the jeep runs MINE. The jeep is THROWN into the air. The convoy halts a there's chaos as soldiers run back pulling people out of vehicles. Hana runs the other way, toward the accident, u she is prevented from reaching Jan’s mangled body by the consoling arms of Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ITALIAN HILL ROAD. LATER
dialogues.text: - and there’s still chaos as two SAPPERS (Bomb Disposal S work on the road ahead. One of them, a SIKH, wears a turb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KIP, the Sikh lieutenant, and HARDY, his sergeant, explor road ahead of the becalmed convoy, using saucer-like META DETECTORS and HEADSETS. Kip is young, lithe, contained, u focused as they inch along the debris-strewn road. He sti as he registers metal. With a bayonet he carefully scrape the mud-caked surface. Something GLEAMS. Suddenly, A PAIR FEET walk across his vision as HANA HURRIES PAST, walking carelessly up the road. It’s so surreal that neither man registers at first, and then Kip is shouting.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Stop! Hey! Now Hardy is shouting for her to stop. Hana looks around.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Don’t move, Stand ABSOLUTELY

dialogues.speaker: STILL
dialogues.text: Hana stops. Hardy gingerly follows her footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (as he approaches) Good, that’s good, just stay still for me and then we'll be fine. He arrives at Hana. Then grabs her. He'd like to slap her

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: What are you doing? What the bloody heli do you think you’re doing? By way of answer she looks at the ground ahead of her fee Jan’s BRACELET lies in the mud. Hardy bends down and coll the mangled bracelet, presses it into Hana’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VILLAGE. DUSK
dialogues.text: The CONVOY is threading through A RUINED VILLAGE, passing souvenirs of war: an overturned vehicle now used as a gam some children, dejected refugees tramping along the side road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hana sees all this as she sits blankly inside the truck, Patient swaying alongside her. She puts out her hand to s him. Tears streak her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CONVOY is making a PIT STOP. The trucks are silhouett a line. Hana helps lift The Patient’s stretcher onto the ground. She bends to him. Hana gets up to prepare a MORPH INJECTION from a small kit. Mary arrives. Touches Hana ge conscious of her grief for Jan‘s death.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Oh god, Hana, you and Jan were inseparable.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (sighs angrily) We keep moving him - in and out of the truck. Why? He’s dying. What's the point?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (thrown ) Do you mean leave him? We can’t. We can hardly leave him. Hana has settled down beside The Patient's stretcher. She herself up against the night. On the hill above, she can the outline of A SMALL MONASTERY in the moonlight. She's suffering, her face a frozen mask.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I must be a curse - anybody who loves me, anybody who gets close to me - or I must be cursed. Which is it? The Patient laces her fingers into his crabbed hand.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MONASTERY. DAY
dialogues.text: Hana is investigating the MONASTERY OF S. ANNA, wandering through its overgrown gardens, past a pond. What sanctuar seems to offer.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MONASTERY LIBRARY. DAY
dialogues.text: Hana explores via a gaping hole in a LIBRARY where the wa have collapsed from sheliing. The garden intrudes, ivy cu around the shelves. Bloated books lie abandoned, and ther PIANO tilted up on one side. Hana presses the keys throug filthy tarpaulin which covers it. Everywhere there are si a brief German occupation.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MONASTERY CLOISTERS. DAY
dialogues.text: Past the Library is a CLOISTERS, drenched with silver lig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hana goes upstairs, negotiating a huge VOID in the stone two thirds of the way up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: She comes across a small CHAPEL with the remains of mural an altar pressed into service by the Germans as a table. finds an old bed and a mattress.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CONVOY SITE, ITALY. DAY
dialogues.text: The Convoy is in the final stages of loading up. Oliver p the vehicles, deep in dispute with a determined Hana, who carrying some sacks of rice.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: When he dies I'1l catch up.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It's not safe here. The whole country's crawling with Bandits and Germans and God knows what.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: The war's over - you told me yourself. How can it be desertion?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It's not over everywhere. I didn’t mean literally. This is normal - it’s shock. For all of us. Hana - Oliver hovers as Hana adds the rice to a small cache of provisions then lays another blanket over The Patient.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I need morphine. A lot. And a pistol.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: If anything happened to you I’d never forgive myself. Hana nods. A tiny smile. Oliver shrugs heiplessly.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: We‘re heading for Leghorn. Livorno the Italians call it. We'll expect you. — 10  INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. DAY. TWO SOLDIERS are helping Mary and Hana carry The Patient what was the chapel. They lower The Patient onto the rust bed. Hana turns to the SOLDIERS.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Thank you. She shuts the door on them, leaving Mary staring aghast a room, its faded frescoes, its mold, its starkness.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Good. She goes to Mary and hugs her. INT. THE MONASTERY, HANA‘S ROOM. DAY A smaller upstairs room, completely bare. As Hana tugs of uniform, she looks out of the window to see the departing Convoy. A cotton dress goes on over her head and she emer looking suddenly younger and rather fragile. Through the damaged floor of her room she has a view of the patient b her. She looks at him. Now she has scissors and starts to off her hair, not aggressively, but in a gesture of a new beginning.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MONASTERY STAIRS. MORNING
dialogues.text: Hana is dropping armfuls of books into the cavities of th damaged stairs while, with others, she is improvising new steps. The heavy volumes are perfect for treading on. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. DAY Hana enters.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: What was all the banging? Were you fighting rats or the entire German army?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I was repairing the stairs. I found a library and the books were very useful. Hana shrugs. She’s attending to him, pulling back the she plumping up the pillows. He’s short of breath.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Before you find too many uses for these books would you read some to me? 11

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I think they’re all in Italian, but I’11 look, yes. What about your own book?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: {reluctant) My book? The Herodotus? Yes, we can read him. Hana picks up the book from the altar and hands it to him she starts rummaging in her pockets.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Oh - I‘ve found plums. We have plums in the orchard. We have an orchard!

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Herodotus is the father of history, do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I don't know anything.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Thank you. She has peeled a plum and now slips it into his mouth. Hi works with the pleasure of the taste, a little juice esca from his lips. Hana mops it up.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: It’s a very plum plum.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MONASTERY GARDENS. DAY
dialogues.text: Hana sits in the water trough shivering as the cold water splashes her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Close on the HERODOTUS. The Patient opens its cover, held together by leather ties. Loose PAPERS, PHOTOGRAPHS, HAND MAPS AND SKETCHES are all collected between the charred p He claws at some papers, inspects a letter. Then he loses control of the papers and the whole parcel SPILLS to the with a crack.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BASE CAMP AT POTTERY HILL. DUSK
dialogues.text: Count Laszlo de Almasy, Hungarian explorer, squats with a ancient Arab who draws in the sand, talking in some arcan dialect, scratching out a map. The old man stops speaking scours the sky a beat or two before we or Almasy hear the noise of a PLANE. It’s a bright yellow Steerman coming in 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: land. Almasy doesn't look up. The Arab continues to talk. plane sweeps past the cluster of tents and camels and tru which constitutes the Base Camp for a team of internation explorers, led by Almasy and his colleague, Peter Madox.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BASE CAMP AT POTTERY HILL. DAY
dialogues.text: The expedition team drives over to meet the arrivals. Alm stays in the car as the others pile out and approach the as it taxis alongside an old, battered silver Tiger Moth. A young couple emerge from the Steerman. They are GEOFFRE KATHARINE CLIFTON. And it’s immediately clear that Katharine is the woman in plane crash at the beginning of the film. Madox makes all the introductions, introducing the rest o team - an Italian, D’Agostino; a German, Bermann; and an Egyptian, FOUAD. Hands are shaken, hellos all round, as t couple disembark in their leather flying gear.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BASE CAMP AT POTTERY HILL. LATE DAY
dialogues.text: The party is in the shade of the tents. Geoffrey Clifton produces a bottle of CHAMPAGNE and sets off the cork with flourish. Almasy joins the group. Madox nods over to the Clifton plane.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: fo the International Sand Club.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: Marvellous plane. Did you look?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: (beaming at Almasy) Isn't it? Wedding present from Katharine's parents. We're calling it Rupert Bear. Hello. Geoffrey Clifton.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: We can finally consign my old bird to the scrap heap. Almasy smiles and walks on towards the others. D‘ AGOSTINO Mrs. Clifton - Count Almasy. 13

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (smiling, offering her hand) Hello. Geoffrey gave me your monograph when I was reading up on the desert. Very impressive.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (stiff) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I wanted to meet a man who could write such a long paper with so few adjectives.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: A thing is still a thing no matter what you place in front of it. Big car, slow car, chauffeur-driven car, still a car.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: (joining them and joining in) A broken car?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Still a car.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: (hands them champagne) Not much use, though.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Love? Romantic love, platonic love, filial love -? Quite different things, surely?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: (hugging Katharine) Uxoriousness - that’s my favourite kind of love. Excessive love of one’s wife.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (a dry smile) Now there you have me. 14

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almasy and Madox head for Madox’s Tiger Moth. They turn t machine around like a toy, pointing it in the right direc for take-off. During this Almasy complains and Madox medi there’s a suspicion that this is a familiar dynamic.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: They‘re tourists.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: Absolute rot. They come highly recommended from the Royal Geographic. She's charming and has read everything, he's meant to be a ruddy good pilot.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: We don‘t need another pilot.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: He can make aerial maps of the entire area.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: You can't explore from the air, Madox. If you could explore from the air life would be very simple. (he primes the propellor) Contact. Madox slips on his goggles and turns on the engine.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: Contact. Almasy spins the propellor. It flashes into life. EXT. GILF KEBIR PLATEAU. MORNING. Both planes are scouting the Gilf Kebir region. Geoffrey up alongside Madox and wiggles his wings. Madox waves. Th flying over a distinctive group of GRANITE MASSIFS, Crate shaped hills. The broken towers of the Gilf Kebir. Almasy distracted by them. He turns to Madox and points down, indicating they should explore them. Madox nods and brings the plane lower and they fly into t mouth of one of the huge craters. The Cliftons’ plane fol them into the black ravines, pitted with signs of scrub. 15 Almasy gestures to the Cliftons to PHOTOGRAPH the Massif THUMBS UP from Geoffrey, who pulls out his camera and beg shooting. INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. MORNING. Hana changes The Patient’s bed. The light streams in from open window. She looks up at the green hills rolling away the Monastery, the village in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I should try and move the bed. I want you to be able to see the view. It's good, it’s a view from a monastery.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I can already see.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (bending down to his level) How? How can you see anything?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: No, not the window - I can’t bear the light anyway - no, I can see all the way to the desert. Before the war. Making maps.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I'm turning you.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Is there sand in my eyes. Are you cleaning sand from my ears?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: No sand, that’s your morphine speaking.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I can see my wife in that view.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Are you remembering more?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Could I have a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? 16

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Why are you so determined to keep me alive?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Because I’m a nurse.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MONASTERY CLOISTERS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s dark. Hana is caught by the stray shafts of moonligh is SCRATCHING on the flagstones. Her skirt is bunched up her thighs. She throws something in the air. It lands wit erack. Suddenly she is flying across the space, a hop, a a jump. Then turns at the other end, dips for the stone, back again, in this blindman‘’s version of HOPSCOTCH.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Alone in his room The Patient listens to the erratic rhyt Hana's hopscotch. It takes him back to the desert and the of Bedouin drums on a night shortly after the arrival of Cliftons.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BASE CAMP. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The group sits around the campfire at night, supper over, champagne drunk. They're using the empty bottle to play a ~ Spin the Bottle. When the bottle points at you, you're required to perform a party piece. Clifton sings a versio ‘Yes, We Have No Bananas,’ then is required to translate into a variety of languages - the others joining in rauco D'Agostino offers a Puccini aria; Fouad dances, his shawi whirling, the Bedouin onlookers providing a percussive, improvised accompaniment. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. NIGHT Later, and Hana is reading to The Patient from a story in Herodotus. As she reads, he listens, eyes closed, still i desert.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: ..-the King insisted he would find some way to prove beyond dispute that his wife was fairest of all women. ‘I will hide you in the room where we sleep’, says Candaules - (correcting herself) - said Candaules. She stumbles over the word. The Patient corrects her.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Candaules. 17

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Candaules.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BASE CAMP AT POTTERY HILL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Katharine has her turn at the fire. She is telling the sa story. The Patient remembers her.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Canduales tells Gyges that the queen has the same practice every night. She takes off her clothes and puts them on the chair by the door to her room...

dialogues.speaker: HANA, (0/S)
dialogues.text: (continuing to read) ...and from where you stand you will be able to gaze on her at your leisure...

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (her story continuing) And that evening it’s exactly as the King has told him. She goes to the chair and removes her clothes one by one until she’s standing naked in full view of Gyges, and indeed she was more lovely than he could have imagined. But then the Queen looked up and saw Gyges concealed in the shadows, and although she said nothing, she shuddered. And the next day she sent for Gyges and challenged him. And hearing his story, this is what she said -

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: (clowning) Off with his head!

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: - she said, “Either you must submit to death for gazing on that which you should not, or else kill my husband who shamed me and become King in his place.” Clifton makes a face of outrage. For Katharine the story suddenly collapsed. She feels Almasy’s eyes on her. 18

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: So Gyges kills the King and marries the Queen and becomes ruler of Lydia for twenty- eight years. (an uncomfortable moment } Shall I spin the bottle? The others laugh. Madox beams at Clifton.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: So Geoffrey ~ let that be a lesson to you.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Hana looks up from the Herodotus, sees The Patient's eyes closed. She gently touches his face and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Are you asleep?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: (he isn’t) Yes. No. Dropping off. And Hana closes the book, gets up, kisses him good night, blows out the lamp. EXT. THE MONASTERY, HANA’S GARDEN. LATE DAY Hana has been reviving a vegetable patch. She comes out t garden. CROWS are feasting. She’s furious, shouts, runs a them. Nature, wildness, insisting on invading her peace.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MONASTERY, GRAVEYARD. MORNING
dialogues.text: Hana appears from the cemetery, dragging A METAL CRUCIFIX bigger than she is, and she drags it along towards her ga A MAN WATCHES HER FROM A BICYCLE, He's approaching fifty, grizzled and attractive, and could be Italian. He wears a of grubby mittens. The man, CARAVAGGIO, chooses this mome introduce himself. He drops the bicycle on the ground wit clatter.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: {very cheerful) Buon Giorno! Hana turns, startled and suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Hana? 19

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: I met your friend Mary. She said I should stop and see if you were all right. Apparently, we're neighbours - my house is two blocks from yours in Montreal. Cabot, north of Laurier. Bonjour.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (unravelling this information} Bonjour. He goes to her and hands her an egg, producing it from a He beams, as does Hana.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: I‘d like to take credit for it, but it’s from Mary. My name’s David Caravaggio, but nobody ever called me David. Caravaggio - they find too absurd to miss out on. During this he attempts to conjure a second egg from Hana ear. THE EGG DROPS TO THE GROUND. Cursing, he gets on his and starts to scoop it up, preserving it. There appears t something wrong with his hands. He grimaces at Hana.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: My stupid hands!

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MONASTERY KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Hana has taken his eggs and put them into a bowl. She bea with a knife, picking out the bits of shell. Caravaggio w takes in how little food there is otherwise. The table se useful more as a sewing area than for cooking - it’s stre altar cloths being sewn into drapes. On a tray on the tab TWO VIALS OF MORPHINE from The Patient’s room. As Hana tu the stove, Caravaggio’s moved and covered them with his g hands a second later and he’s juggled them into his pocke

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: (of the eggs) They're fresh. I haven’t had an egg in...have you noticed there are chickens? In Italy you get chickens but no eggs. In Africa there were always eggs, but never chickens. Who separated them? 20

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (intrigued) You were in Africa?

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Yes I was.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: So was my Patient.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Look, I’d like to stay for a while. I have to do some work here - I speak the language. There are Partisans to be disarmed - (trying to paraphrase) - we embrace them and see if we can relieve them of their weapons, you know - while we hug. I was a thief, so the Army thought I'd be good at it.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: So you can shoot a pistol?

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: (showing his hands) No.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Do you have a problem with those?

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I should iook at them before you go.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Look, it’s a big place. We needn't disturb each other. I’1l sleep in the stabie. It doesn't matter where I sleep. I don‘t sleep.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I don’t know what Mary told you about me, but I don’t need company, I don’t need to be iooked after. 21  INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. DAY Hana carries in a tray. There's OMELETTE on the plate.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: There's a man downstairs. He brought us eggs. He might stay.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Why? Can he lay eggs?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: He’s Canadian.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: (brittle) Why are people always so happy when they collide with someone from the same place? What happened in Montreal when you passed a man in the street - did you invite him to live with you?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: He needn‘t disturb you.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Me? He can't. I’m already disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (she cuts the omelette into tiny pieces) There's a war. Where you come from becomes important.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Why? I hate that idea.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MONASTERY STAIRS. DAY
dialogues.text: Caravaggio is in shadows in the hallway. He listens. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. DAY Hana, having already replaced the bed linen, is standing stepladder trying to hang homemade drapes around the bed Caravaggio knocks tentatively, then comes in.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: It’s finished. 22

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: So you’re our Canadian pickpocket?

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Thief, I think, is more accurate.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I understand you were in Africa. Whereabouts?

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Oh, all over.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: All over? I kept trying to cover a very modest portion and still failed. {to Hana, who is heading out) Are you leaving us?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Now’s our opportunity to swap war wounds.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Then I'm definitely going. And she exits. The men consider her.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Does she have war wounds? INT. THE MONASTERY, HANA‘S ROOM. DAY As Hana walks up her stairs she finds herself overhearing conversation as it threads up through the hole in the cei She strips her own bed of the curtain she uses for a shee

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I think anybody she ever loves tends to die on her.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Are you planning to be the exception? 23

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Me? I think you’ve got the wrong end of the stick, old boy. (a pause) So, Caravaggio ~ Hana thinks you invented your name.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: And you’ve forgotten yours.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I said that no one would ever invent such a preposterous name.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: I said you can forget everything but you never forget your name. Count Almasy - that name mean anything to you? Or Katharine Clifton?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAIRO MARKET. DAY
dialogues.text: A STREET MARKET in full sway, a locals-only affair, blazi with noise and bustle and barter. Emerging from a thicket women and begging children, KATHARINE CLIFTON carries her purchase of an exotic-looking Carpet. From nowhere she is joined by ALMASY, who nods at the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: How much did you pay?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (delighted) Oh, Hello!

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: They don‘t see foreign women in this market. How much did you pay?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Seven, eight pounds, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Which stall?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Why? 24

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: You've been cheated, don’t worry, we'll take it back.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (bristling) I don’t want to take it back.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: This is not worth eight pounds, Mrs. Clifton.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: It is to me.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Did you bargain?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I don't care to bargain.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: That insults them.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (turning to face him) I don't believe that. I think you are insulted by me, somehow.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (of the carpet) I'd be very happy to obtain the correct price for this. I apologize if I appear abrupt. I am rusty at social graces. (tart) How do you find Cairo? Did you visit the Pyramids?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Or the Sphinx? He stands as she continues, pushing past him, boiling.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL, CAIRO. EVENING
dialogues.text: THE LONG BAR. The Exploration Team drinking at a table. T are not entirely off-duty - Almasy and Madox, as ever, po the maps. 25

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: By car? Impossible. If we try and drive north of Kufra by car, we’ll leave our bones in the desert.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Disagree.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: You’re Hungarian, you always disagree. Geoffrey Clifton appears.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Good evening, Gentlemen! He sits down. Madox hails the waiter. D‘AGOSTINO How is your charming wife?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Marvellous. She’s in love with the hotel plumbing. She's either in the swimming pool - she swims for hours, she’s a fish, quite incredible ~ or she’s in the bath. Actually, she’s just outside. (responding to their bewildered expressions) Chaps Only in the Long Bar. EXT. SHEPHEARD’S HOTEL TERRACE. NIGHT The Explorers, embarrassed, march out onto the terrace. Katharine sits, reading, exquisite in her evening clothes There is dancing inside, and couples walk to and from the tables. Madox approaches to collect her. Katharine manage produce a dazzling smile which includes everyone except A

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: Mrs. Clifton, you'll have to forgive us. We’re not accustomed to the company of women.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Not at all. I was thoroughly enjoying my book. 26

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: The team is in mourning, darling.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Oh really?

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: I’m afraid we’re not having much luck obtaining funds for the expedition.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Oh. What will you do?

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: A more modest expedition, or even wait a year. Remind our families we still exist.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: (astonished) Good heavens, are you Married, Madox?

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: Very much so. We all are, save my friend here. He nods at Almasy. Clifton appears tremendously relieved.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: I feel much better, don’t you darling? We were feeling rather self-conscious. Let's toast, then. To absent wives. D‘ AGOSTINO (toasting Katharine) And present ones.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (toasting Almasy) And future ones. INT. SHEPHEARD’S HOTEL. NIGHT THE BALLROOM. A dance finishes. Almasy takes over from D‘Agostino to partner Katharine. The others remain on the terrace, deep in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (as they dance) Why did you follow me yesterday? 27

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: What? I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: After the market, you followed me to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I was concerned. A woman in that part of Cairo, a European woman, I felt obliged to.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You felt obliged to.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: As the wife of one of our party.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (direct) So why follow me? Escort me, by all means. But following me is predatory, isn’t it? Almasy, by way of answer, bears down on her. They dance, fierce, oblivious to everything. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. NIGHT Hana has fallen asleep on the bed, almost on top of the Patient. He touches her. He speaks as if each word burns

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Could I ask you to move? I’m sorry -

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (mortified, moving quickly) I'm sorry, of course. I was dreaming. Awful.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: It’s just when you move -

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: How stupid of me.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I can’t really bear the pressure. Hana gets up, upset to have hurt him. 28

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hana comes to the table, carrying a jug of water and a bo She’s still sad. She unbuttons her dress, pulling it off shoulder, begins to pour the water to cool herself agains night's pressing heat. She’s overwhelmed by memories, by weight of her curse. Caravaggio comes into the kitchen to her slumped at the table, her back naked, the jug of wate front of her. She's sobbing, her shoulders heaving. Carav approaches tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Hana? (he touches her shoulder) Hana? Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (without raising her head) Don‘t touch me. She pulls her dress up around her shoulders. Her face is with weeping. Caravaggio pours a glass of water and walks the open window.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: You’re in love with him, aren’t you? Your poor patient. Do you think he’s a saint because of the way he looks? I don’t think he is.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I'm not in love with him. I'm in love with ghosts. So is he. He’s in love with ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: (he holds up his hands) What if I told you he did this to me?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (stung) How could he have? When?

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: I'm one of his ghosts and he wouldn’t even know it.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I don’t know what that means. 29

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Ask your saint who he is. Ask him who he‘s killed.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (furious) Please don’t creep around this house! She leaves, slamming the door behind her. Caravaggio call after her.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: I don’t think he's forgotten anything. I think he wants to forget.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TENT, BASE CAMP AT POTTERY HILL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The group of expeditioners is around the fire. Clifton ho a glass.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, to Map-making!

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Map-making!

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: And a special thank-you to Geoffrey and Katharine, without whose fund-raising heroics we’d still be kicking our heels.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: To arm-twisting.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: (to Almasy) Did Katharine say? Geoffrey has to fly back to Cairo.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Return the favour - take a few photographs of the army.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: What kind of photographs? 30

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Portraits. The Brigadier, the Brigadier's wife, the Brigadier’s dogs, the Brigadier by the Pyramids, the Brigadier breathing. I shall of course be bereft, but finally able to explore the Cairo nightlife. I shall produce an authoritative guide to the Zinc Bars and - I want to say Harems ~ are we in the right country for Harems?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BASE CAMP AT POTTERY HILL. MORNING
dialogues.text: As Clifton prepares to leave in the Steerman, Almasy approaches.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Clifton, safe journey.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: You too. Good luck!

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Clifton - it’s probably none of my business - but your wife, do you think it's appropriate to leave her?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Appropriate?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Well the desert is - for a woman - it’s very tough, I wonder if it’s not too much for her.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Are you mad? Katharine loves it here. She told me yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: All the same, were I you, I would be concerned - 31

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: I‘ve known Katharine since she was three, we were practically brother and sister before we were man and wife. I think I'd know what is and what isn’t too much for her. I think she'd know herself.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Very well.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: (laughing it off) Why are you people so threatened by a woman?! Almasy watches him walk toward the plane, then turns to s Katharine, a distant figure, watching. He doesn’t move. S doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MONASTERY LIBRARY. DAY
dialogues.text: Hana stands at the PIANO. It’s still lop-sided, propped a the wall. She tries but can’t move it. So she pulls off t sheet and, with the instrument still on a tilt, begins to out the Aria from Bach's Goldberg Variations. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. DAY HANA’S PIANO CONTINUES. Upstairs, Caravaggio chats with T Patient while working his arm to RAISE A VEIN, a bootlace around it, preparing an injection for himself, tapping th syringe. During this:

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I have come to love that little tap of the fingernail against the syringe. Tap. Tap. Tap.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MONASTERY LIBRARY. DAY
dialogues.text: Hana plays. A GUNSHOT punctuates the music. Her hands fal she looks up to see A SIKH SOLDIER running past the GAPIN IN THE WALL, his rifle held aloft. He approaches the fren doors, his face creased with anxiety, and raps on the sha frame. It’s KIP, the bomb disposal officer who had cleare road on which Jan's jeep had exploded.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Stop playing! Please, Stop Playing! 32

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (of the doors) I don’t have the key to that door. She watches him walk around from the locked doors and wal straight through the hole in the wall, oblivious to any i and up to the piano.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: The Germans were here. The Germans were all over this area. They left mines everywhere. And pianos were their favourite hiding places.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I see. Sorry. (then mischievous) Then maybe you’re safe as long as you only play Bach. He's German. Kip is looking around the piano. Hana giggles.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Is something funny?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: No, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: I’ve met you before.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Look. See. See. Hana bends to see what Kip’s looking at under the piano. run from the wall to the instrument onto which is taped a EXPLOSIVE CHARGE. If Hana had succeeded in moving the pia would have triggered the charge. Kip looks at Hana, who conceals her dismay with a shrug.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: (of the piano) Move that, and no more Bach.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MONASTERY GARDEN. DUSK
dialogues.text: Across from the terrace, KIP and his sergeant, HARDY, are putting up their tents. Caravaggio stands, chatting amiab them, holding a haversack, smoking a cigarette. 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hana looks down from The Patient's room, watching the ten up. Kip glances up at the window. Hana, suddenly shy, bac away.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: He wants us to move out, says there could be fifty more mines in the building. He thinks I’m mad because I laughed at him. He’s Indian, he wears a turban.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: No he’s Sikh. If he wears a turban, he’s Sikh.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I‘11 probably marry him.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Really? That’s sudden.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: My mother always told me I would summon my husband by playing the piano. She bathes The Patient.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I liked it better when there were just the two of us.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: (irked) Why? Is he staying?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: With his Sergeant. A Mr. Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: We should charge! Doesn't anyone have a job to do?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: They have to clear all the roads of mines. That’s a big job.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: In that case, I suppose we can’t charge. 34

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: No, we can't. EXT. THE MONASTERY, HANA’S GARDEN. DAY HANA IS GARDENING, close to the crucifix, which is now a fledged Scarecrow. Broken bottles, fragments of stained g and shards from a mirror are hung from the crossbar, syri too, all jangling and tinkling and catching the sunlight. Kip and Hardy drive off to work on their motorcycles. She watches them, catching Kip’s careless wave to her. She lo briefly at herself in A PIECE OF MIRROR dangling from the Scarecrow.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: The Patient lies in bed singing to himself in Arabic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The THREE FORD CARS leave the campsite, loaded for a scou expedition. The rest of the party, Bedouin, tents, camels Tiger Moth - is left behind.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR EN ROUTE TO CAVE OF SWIMMERS. DAY
dialogues.text: Almasy drives the second car, accompanied by Katharine an Auf, who sits on top of the cabin. Almasy sings as they d Katharine breaks the long silence between them.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I’ve been thinking - how does somebody like you decide to come to the desert? What is it? You’re doing whatever you're doing - in your castle, or wherever it is you live - and one day you say I have to go to the desert - or what? Almasy doesn’t answer. Katharine, who has looked at him f answer, looks away. There's another long silence.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I once travelled with a guide, who was taking me to Faya. He didn't speak for nine hours. At the end of it he pointed at the horizon and said, “Faya!” That was a good day. Point made, they lapse again into silence. Katharine boil 35

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Actually, you sing.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You sing. All the time.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I do not.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Ask Al Auf. In Arabic, Almasy asks Al Auf, who promptly laughs, nods sings a snatch of what he thinks is the tune to ‘The Dark Strutter’s Ball’. Katharine, delighted, joins in.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (sings wickedly) I‘1l be down to get you in the taxi, honey, you'd better be ready about half-past eight... Al Auf nods and grins furiously, joins in, impersonating Almasy. Almasy makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, NEAR THE BASE CAMP AT THE CAVE OF SWIMMERS. DUSK
dialogues.text: The group is investigating a cleft in the rocky massif. T climb slowly. Below them, A NEW AND TEMPORARY BASE CAMP. The group winds around the rock. Almasy turns to offer a to Katharine behind him, pulling her up to the next rock The group stops at a level plateau. The Arabs stand apart SING THEIR PRAYERS AT DUSK. Al Auf leads the incantations

dialogues.speaker: AL AUF
dialogues.text: Allah Akbar, Allahu Akbar... The Westerners wait respectfully. As the sun sets in glor Almasy looks over at the range of rocks. One particular r seems to look exactly like A WOMAN’S BACK. He squints at rocks, then pulls out his Herodotus to compare his sketch with the terrain in front of him. 36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almasy clambers up the rocks, coming through a narrow cre to find A NATURAL SHELF. He scrambles up this path, reach up, only to notice that his hand almost perfectly covers CARVED HAND on the rock, and as he digests this he realiz has climbed past what is THE MOUTH OF A CAVE. He disappea inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FLASHLIGHT squirts into the cave. Almasy treads cautiou along the narrow winding passage. He comes to an open cav and takes his flashlight up to a wall. Almasy is astonish what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEAR THE CAVE OF SWIMMERS. EVENING
dialogues.text: The others watch as a flashlight bobs and jerks among the and Almasy comes scrambling down, transformed into an exc teenager.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Madox! Madox! Madox, come quickly! Bermann, D'Ag - I’ve found something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAINTINGS EMERGE, figures, animals. Ancient pictures. A giraffe. Cattle. Fish. Men with bows and arrows. Almasy h the whole party into the heart of the cave. Now Madox com alongside him at the wall, his flashlight joining Almasy’ increasing the visibility of the paintings. A dark-skinne figure, apparently in the process of DIVING into water, c clearly into view. Then others, supine, arms outstretched

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: (with audible excitement) My God, they’re swimming! They're swimming! The others crowd around. Five excited faces in the green of the cave.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAVE OF SWIMMERS. DAY
dialogues.text: Katharine is painting. She copies the cave paintings with meticulous, almost scientific accuracy. 37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hive of activity. The team has set up TRESTLES to catal the finds as the Bedouin come out with baskets of detritu which they empty onto a growing heap as the Cave is clear out. Almasy clambers inside carrying camera equipment.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAVE OF SWIMMERS. DAY
dialogues.text: Inside, Bermann is setting up LAMPS, running wires from a BATTERY. Kamal is helping him. And as Almasy arrives he c a tiny moment of tenderness between them. Bermann, seeing quickly disengages and busies himself with the lights.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DESERT. DAY
dialogues.text: The CARS are heading back to Base Camp. They bounce over sand. INT. BERMANN’S CAR. DAY Bermann is driving the lead CAR along some STEEP DUNES. A beside him. Bermann is peeling AN ORANGE, a segment of wh holds out of the window. Kamal, riding shotgun, leans dow collects it, his head dipping in to grin at Bermann. Berm looks uneasily at Almasy. He wants to tell him of his pas of his absolute love for Kamal, but he daren’t.

dialogues.speaker: BERMANN
dialogues.text: How do you explain? To someone who’s never been here? Feelings which seem guite normal.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (compassionate) I don’t know, my friend. I don’t know. Bermann holds out another segment of the orange, and watc Kamal bend into view, opening his mouth to be fed another piece, then suddenly fall from the vehicle. THE CAR LURCH SIDEWAYS AND TOPPLES OVER THE EDGE. D’Ag - following, Fou beside him - brakes sharply, but can’t stop his own car f being caught in the avalanche of sand, and IT PLUNGES DOW DUNE AND INTO BERMANN’S UPTURNED CAR WITH AN OMINOUS CRUN the radiator exploding. Only Madox, a little way behind, Katharine beside him, manages to stay clear of trouble. H jumps out of the vehicle and slides down the dune to find pandemonium as the passengers stumble out of the cars, sa flying, smoke pouring from the upright vehicle, the wheel the overturned car spinning wildly in the air, a puddle o spreading ominously. 38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER and the group have cleaned up as best as possible. Bermann, and Fouad are a little worse for wear. Fouad’s a in a sling, and D’Ag is sporting a bloody head bandage. B has broken a finger and is being attended to by Madox. Th luggage, water, and petrol have been stacked up and the m loading the remaining car.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DESERT. DAY
dialogues.text: Almasy, Kamal and two of the other young Bedouin stand ar the mess of the two broken vehicles. The ONE WORKING CAR loaded with men and provisions. Katharine sits inside, ne Madox. Almasy comes over to her window, to speak past her Madox.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: I'll be back as quick as I can. Thirty-six hours at the outside.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Try to get an additional radiator. We can store it between here and Pottery Hill. And a better jack. We planned badly.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: (nods at Almasy, then shouts over to the wrecked vehicles) Bermann! This is Bermann’s cue to take leave of Kamal, who is stay behind. Kamal makes a little bow.

dialogues.speaker: KAMAL
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) May God make safety your companion. Bermann nods and hurries away, squeezing into the car, wh jolts off, bouncing over the track. The vehicle gets about twenty yards, Almasy watching, bef sinks forlornly into the soft sand. It’s hopelessly overl with people. They all get out.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: (irascible) Now what?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I‘1l stay behind, of course. 39

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: Certainly not.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: No, I insist. There clearly isn’t room for all of us, I’m the least able to dig, and I’m not one of the walking wounded. It’s only one night! Besides, if I remain it’s the most effective method of persuading my husband to abandon whatever he’s doing and come and rescue us. It's hard to argue with this logic. Almasy shrugs. LATER - THE MADOX CAR makes a more effective departure. A watches it disappear then turns, uncomfortable, to see Katharine walk down the steep face of the dune toward the makeshift shelter.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SHELTER. DAY
dialogues.text: Almasy sits alone, writing into HIS HERODOTUS, a map fold front of him, from which he makes notes. Katharine comes with a clutch of her SKETCHES from the Cave wall. Hands t him. They’re beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I thought you might like to paste them into your book.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Well, we took photographs, there’s no need.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: No really, I’d like you to have them.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (handing them back) Well, there is really no need. They're too good. This is just a scrapbook. I should feel obliged. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (exasperated) And that would be unconscionable, I suppose, wouldn't it, to feel any obligation? Yes. Of course it would. 40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She’s already turning, heading back up the slope, leaving perimeter of the shelter. EXT. THE DESERT. NIGHT. Katharine sits alone on top of the Dune, smoking, surveyi landscape. Below her the camp - a fresh wind flicking at tarpaulin, The deep tracks of Madox’s car stretching off towards civilization. Almasy heads up towards her.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: You should come into the shelter.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I'm quite all right, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Look over there. Katharine turns, scans the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: What am I looking at?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Do you see what's happening to them - the stars?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: They’re so untidy. I’m just trying to rearrange them.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: No, no, over there. In a few minutes there will be no stars. The air is filling with sand. On the distant dunes an ominous, boiling cloud.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VEHICLES. NIGHT
dialogues.text: . The team hurries around salvaging gasoline drums, water bringing anything loose or light inside the vehicles. The is whipping up. the air busy with sand. Chaos as they str in ever-worsening conditions, their heads wrapped in blan flashlights useless. They seek safety in two groups, the tribesmen to the cabin of the overturned car, Katharine a Almasy to the upright one. 41

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the cabin, the sand swirling around them, Katharin Almasy sit without speaking. He pours a little water so t they can wash out their eyes and noses and mouths. She ta her silk scarf, wets it, presses it to her face.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: This is not very good, is it?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Shall we be all right?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Yes is a comfort. Absolutely is not.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DESERT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The sand is piling up against the two cars, the tent is s from its moorings, the water cans are hurled up, too, and plunge ominously into sand drifts as if going under an oc

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY, (0/S)
dialogues.text: ..-let me tell you about winds. There is a whirlwind from Southern Morocco, the Aajej, against which the fellahin defend themselves with knives. And there is the Ghibli from Tunis which rolls and rolls and rolls and produces a rather strange nervous condition... And we hear Katharine’s laugh.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Almasy sits alongside Katharine, whose head is against hi shoulder. He continues his story of winds.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: -+.and then there is the Harmatton, a red wind which Mariners call the sea of darkness. Red sand from this wind has flown as far as the south coast of England apparently producing showers 42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMASY (cont ‘d) so dense they were mistaken for blood...

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Fiction. We have a house on that coast, and it has never, never rained blood.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: No, it’s all true. (teasing her) Herodotus, your friend -

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (laughs) My friend!

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: - he writes about it and he writes about a wind, the Simoon, which a nation thought was so evil they declared war on it and marched out against it in full battle dress. He's touching Katharine's hair, he can’t help it. She is paralysed by his touch, then puts out her hand and traces across the window, now entirely silted up with sand. INT. PATIENT’S ROOM. NIGHT. The Patient remembers. He feels Katharine’s fingers traci across his face.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DESERT. DAY
dialogues.text: MORNING. The sand has almost COMPLETELY ENGULFED the car exposed side, covering the windscreen like snow, and encroaching onto the door of the protected flank. INT. CAR. DAY. Almasy is awaken by the sound of A DISTANT ENGINE. He jer waking Katharine in the process, and heaves against the d

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Quick. Katharine. Quick, wake up! I can hear a car. Let me out. (he stumbles out of the car, up the dune, then stops and flies back to the car) The flare! 43

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMASY (cont‘d) (berating himself) Idiot! To fall asleep. Unforgiveable.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DESERT. DAY
dialogues.text: MADOX’S CAR IS ROARING ALONG THE HORIZON. Almasy runs bac the car, finds his flaregun, and SENDS A FLARE high into sky. Katharine is with him now, and they watch, helplessl the car bounces away from them, Madox a man on a mission. Katharine panics, THE SAND HAS ERASED ALL TRACE OF THEM. Katharine waves her arms frantically.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Here! We’re here! Stop!

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Madox! Madox!

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Our tracks have disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Madox will calculate how many miles; he'll soon turn around. Katharine is frightened. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Could I ask you, please, to paste your paintings into my book? I should like to have them. I should be honoured. A car horn leaks into their conversation. Almasy can't pl at first ~ he’d assumed it was Madox. Now he realises it' coming from the floor of the sand dune. He suddenly turns charges away from Katharine.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: The others! Katharine, horrified, follows him towards the mound of sa which has completely buried the other vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Awful. We must get them out! How awful. Almasy is preoccupied. He’s gone back to their vehicle an returns with a shovel, STARTS TO DIG FRANTICALLY. Kathari kneels beside him and helps to shovel away the sand. Duri this: 44

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Am I a terrible coward to ask how much water we have?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (shovelling hard) We have a little in our can, we have water in the radiator which can be drunk. It’s not cowardly at all, it’s extremely practical. (anxious at not uncovering the boys, egging himself on) Come on, come on! (then back to Katharine) There's also a plant - I believe you can cut a piece the size of a heart from this plant and the next morning it will be filled with a delicious liquid.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Find that plant. Cut out its heart. They hear NOISES, scrabbling, faint thumps. Almasy scrape the sand and they find the glass of the car. The angle of cab, tilted up to the sky, has made it impossible for the trapped boys to lever it open. Their oxygen is rapidly deteriorating. Almasy pulls on the door and it cranks ope boys, dazed, guiping in the fresh air, clamber out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DESERT. DAY
dialogues.text: Katharine sits in the car, putting her pictures into the Herodotus. It’s full of ALMASY’S HANDWRITING, PHOTOGRAPHS PRESSED FLOWERS. She deciphers a page of his words and drawings. It's almost exclusively about her, the lines st with Ks. She reads, astonished, then looks at him as he a of the three Bedouin circle the area of the cars in ever- widening circles, like water-diviners, like Kip searching mines. Almasy suddenly drops to his knees and begins to s into the sand. He pulis out A CAN OF WATER. Turns to Kath and holds it triumphantly in the air.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE DESERT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A red umbrella of light as Almasy fires the last flare in black night. Katharine comes up beside him. They wait in silence, hope fading with the flare. 45

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (blank) Geoffrey's not in Cairo. (Almasy looks at her) He's not actually a buffoon. And the plane wasn’t a wedding present. It belongs to the British Government. They want aerial maps of the whole of North Africa. So I think he's in Ethiopia. In case you were counting on his sudden appearance.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: And the marriage - is that a fiction? There’s a beat. Katharine has a hundred answers.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: No, the marriage isn't a fiction. The light from the flare fades on them and they stand in dark. Suddenly on the far horizon, behind their heads, an answering flare fireworks into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Thank God. Oh thank God. There's excited shouting from the boys. Then a distant re Almasy laughs with relief.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: It’s Madox. He turns to Katharine. She shudders.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Am I K in your book? I think I must be. Almasy turns to her. He runs the blade of his arm across neck.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MONASTERY, UPSTAIRS LANDING. DAY
dialogues.text: Hana walks along the landing with a tray. There’s a messa several doors in the corridor from Kip: SAFE, then a coup with the warning: DANGER. She hears noise from The Patien room. Listens for a second before going in. Kip is readin The Patient. 46

dialogues.speaker: KIP, (0/8)
dialogues.text: (reading) “He sat, in defiance of municipal orders, astride the gun Zamzammah on her brick platform opposite the old Ajaib-Gher -” (he breaks off) I can’t read these words. They stick in my throat.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT, (0/S)
dialogues.text: Because you're reading it too fast!

dialogues.speaker: KIP, (0/S)
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT, (0/S)
dialogues.text: You have to read Kipling slowly! Your eye is too impatient - think about the speed of his pen. (quoting Kipling to demonstrate) What is it? “He sat” comma “in defiance of municipal orders” comma “astride the gun Zamzammah on her brick”... what is it? INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. DAY During this, Hana comes through with the tray, finds Kip perched on the window, relishing his skirmish with The Pa who has condensed milk dribbling down his neck.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: “Brick platform opposite the old Ajaib-Gher -”

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: “— The Wonder House” comma “as the natives called the Lahore Museum.”

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: It’s still there, the cannon, outside the museum. It was made of metal cups and bowls taken from every household in the city as tax, then melted down. Then later they fired the cannon at my people comma the natives. Full stop. 47

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: So what is it you object to - the writer or what he’s writing about?

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: What I really object to, Uncle, is your finishing all my condensed milk. (snatching up the empty can) And the message everywhere in your book - however slowly I read it - that the best destiny for India is to be ruled by the British.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Hana, we have discovered a shared pleasure - the boy and I.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Arguing about books.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Condensed milk - one of the truly great inventions.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: (grinning, leaving) I’1l get another tin. Hana and The Patient are alone.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I didn’t like that book either. It’s all about men. Too many men. Just like this house.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: You like him, don’t you? Your voice changes.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I don’t think it does. {a beat) Anyway, he’s indifferent to me.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I don’t think it's indifference. Kip comes bounding in with a fresh can. 48

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Hana was just telling me you were indifferent -

dialogues.speaker: BANA
dialogues.text: (appalled) Hey! -

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: - to her cooking.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: (oblivious) Well, I’m indifferent to cooking, not Hana’s cooking in particular. (stabbing at the tin with a bayonet) Have either of you ever tried condensed milk sandwiches?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAIRO. DAY
dialogues.text: ANOTHER WORLD as a honking TAXI containing Almasy and Kat negotiates the pell-mell bustle of Cairo. EXT. SHEPHEARD’S HOTEL. DAY Almasy, still in the same clothes, and evidently weary, e from the cab, and pulls Katharine’s belongings from the t then holds open the door for her. As she walks toward the hotel, he hands her bag to a porter. Katharine is stung.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Will you not come in?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: No. I should go home.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: will you please come in?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (a beat) Mrs. Clifton - Katharine turns, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Don’t.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I believe you still have my book. 49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katharine fishes the book from her knapsack, shoves it at then disappears. INT. ALMASY’S ROOM. DAY Almasy lying on a camp bed, face down. The walls are cove with maps, enlargements of photographs. A fan whirs over kit which is spread, unravelled but ordered, on the stone floor. An ineffably male room, the shutters closed, just thinnest shaft of light piercing the gloom. Almasy hasn’t removed his clothes, his boots kicked off below his jutti feet. There’s A KNOCK at the door. Almasy sleeps. Another. A th He's roused from the dead. It's Katharine. She’s bathed, luminous, stands backlit by afternoon sun - an angel in a cotton dress. He walks towa her and she slaps him shockingly hard. He KNEELS before h head at her thighs. Katharine beats on his head and shoul violently, then stops, her face expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You still have sand in your hair. He pulls back, to look at her. She kneels and covers his with kisses. He pulls blindly at her dress and it RIPS ac her breasts.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BATHROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Almasy is in the bath. Katharine, wearing his dressing go pours in a jug of steaming water. Almasy leans over the r the bath. He’s singing and sewing, carefully repairing th dress.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I’m impressed you can sew.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You sew very badly.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: You don’t sew at all!

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: A woman should never learn to sew, and if she can she shouldn’t admit to it. Close your eyes. 50

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (laughs) That makes it harder still. She pushes the sewing from his hands, then pours water ov head, then begins to shampoo his hair. Almasy is in heaven. The biggest smile we have seen from She continues to massage his scalp.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: When were you most happy?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: When were you least happy?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (a beat) Now.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: What do you love?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: What do I love?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Say everything.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Let me see... I love water, the fish in it. Hedgehogs! I love hedgehogs. She rinses his hair, then slips off the robe and CLIMBS I BESIDE HIM, covering his neck and shoulders in kisses.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: And what else?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Marmite - I'm addicted! Baths ~- but not with other people! Islands. Your handwriting. I could go on all day.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (kissing her) Go on all day.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (a beat) My husband. 51

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almasy looks away.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: What do you hate most?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: A lie. What do you hate most?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Ownership. Being owned. When you leave, you should forget me. She freezes, pushes him away, pulls herself out of the ba She picks up her dress, the thread and needle dangling fr and walks, dripping, out of the room. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. DAY Hana sits reading from the Herodotus. She pulis out a photograph of a small child.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Don’t you recognize me?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (Laughs) Is it you? So fat! Next she shows The Patient the page where a CHRISTMAS CRA WRAPPER covered in handwriting has been glued in.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: That's a Christmas cracker. It was a Christmas cracker. A firecracker.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: This isn't your handwriting, is it?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Yes, it is.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: {she reads what he’s written) “December twenty-second ~ Betrayals in war are childlike compared with our betrayals during peace. New lovers are nervous and 52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANA (cont'd) tender, but smash everything _ for the heart is an organ of fire...for the heart is an organ of fire...” (she looks up) I love that, I pelieve that. (to him) K. Who is K?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: K is for Katharine. EXT. AMBASSADOR’ S RESIDENCE, DECEMBER 1938. DAY A CHRISTMAS PARTY FOR THE TROOPS, The incongruous attempt create a traditional Christmas in the dusty heat of Cairo party is in the courtyard of the Moorish Palace, which se as the private residence of the British Ambassador, SIR R HAMPTON. Lots of wives, including LADY HAMPTON and Kathar help serve tea and cake to the SOLDIERS who sit at rudime tables with paper plates and paper hats. A man dressed as CLAUS is giving out presents — PENGUIN PAPERBACKS , CHOCO Christmas carols leak from a loudspeaker. Officers and Civilians walk the perimeter. one of these, arriving, is Almasy. He sits in the shade, catches Katharine’s attenti Katharine brings him over a cup of tea and a plate with Christmas cake on it.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Say you're sick.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: What? No!

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Say you're feeling faint - the heat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (put a frisson) No.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: t can’t work. T can’t sleep. Lady Hampton calls impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: LADY HAMPTON
dialogues.text: Katharine! 53

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Coming. (to Almasy) I can't sleep. I woke up shouting in the middle of the night. Geoffrey thinks it’s the thing in the desert, the trauma.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I can still taste you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
