dialogues.text: (waving at another woman who pushes a trolley with teapots) Philippa, this is empty.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I‘m trying to write with your taste in my mouth. (as she leaves) Swoon. I‘1l catch you. Almasy sits watching the party. The Santa Claus is dragge outside by some excited Children. Almasy picks at his cak removing the thick marzipan icing. He’s writing on A CHRI CRACKER WRAPPER, smoothing it out - “December 22nd. Betra in war are childlike compared with our betrayals du -" Katharine, attending to a table, suddenly sags at the kne and SWOONS. People rush to her.

dialogues.speaker: LADY HAMPTON
dialogues.text: Katharine!

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I’m fine. No, I’m fine. How silly.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER'S WIFE
dialogues.text: (helping her to sit down) It’s the heat.

dialogues.speaker: LADY HAMPTON
dialogues.text: (to the others) She’s quite all right. (solicitous) Are you pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. 54

dialogues.speaker: LADY HAMPTON
dialogues.text: (squeezing her arm) How romantic. With Fiona I fell over every five minutes. Ronnie christened me Lady Downfall.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Do you know, I think I might go inside and sit down for a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: LADY HAMPTON
dialogues.text: I‘11 come with you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: No, please. You stay. I shall be absolutely fine. INT. STOREROOM. AMBASSADOR’S RESIDENCE. DAY A small STOREROOM inside the Palace - Brooms, Mops, Clean Equipment. Outside, the party is visible as opaque shadow through the bevelled glass of the ornate window. The soun carols sung by the enlisted men gives way to a version of “SILENT NIGHT” played on a solitary bagpipe. Inside, Alma Katharine make love in the darkness. It’s as if the world stopped and there’s only their passion, overwhelming reas logic and rules. INT. CORRIDORS, AMBASSADOR’S RESIDENCE. DAY A CORRIDOR. Almasy appears and almost immediately collide the man dressed as SANTA CLAUS.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Have you seen Katharine?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (taken aback) What?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: (pulling down his beard) It’s Clifton under here.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I haven't, sorry. INT. SIDE ROOM IN AMBASSADOR’S RESIDENCE. ‘DAY Geoffrey continues scouring the warren of tiny rooms that off the central courtyard. He finds Katharine sitting in smoking, surrounded by oppressive and elaborate tiling. C wonders briefly how Almasy had missed Katharine. 55

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Darling, I just heard. You poor sausage, are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I’m just hot.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Lady H said she thought you might be pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I’m not pregnant. I’m just hot. Too hot. Aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: I'm sweltering, actually. (taking off his hat and beard) Come on, I’11 take you home.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (close to tears) Can't we really go home? I can't breathe. Aren’t you dying for green, anything green, or rain. It’s Christmas and it’s all - oh, I don‘t know - if you asked me I’d go home tomorrow. If you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Darling, you know we can't go home, there might be a war.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (poking at his costume) Oh, Geoffrey, you do so love a disguise.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: I do so love you. (he kisses her head) What do you smell of?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (horrified) What?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Marzipan! I think you've got marzipan in your hair. No wonder you're homesick. 56  INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. EVENING The Patient lies alone in his room. Then something distra him. Caravaggio is standing over him, staring, intense.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Is it you?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: If I said Moose.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Moose? Who the hell’s Moose? Caravaggio comes close, scrutinizing the face, trying to the features. Exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: I look different, why shouldn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I heard your breathing, I thought it was the rain. I'm dying for rain. I'm dying anyway, but I long for the rain on my face.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: (a different tack) First wedding anniversary -~ what do you call it?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Paper. Is it? (sharp, not wanting to think) I don’t know. Paper.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OFFICE, BRITISH HQ, CAIRO. DAY
dialogues.text: A SMALL OFFICE, shared by two men, and a mountain of fili cabinets and paper. There are AERIAL MAPS all over the wa Clifton is on the telephone, while his colleague, RUPERT DOUGLAS, works at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: {into the phone) Darling, it’s me, I'm sorry, something’s come up.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE, (0/S)
dialogues.text: Oh no. 57

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Don’t sulk - I’11 be back tomorrow evening. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE, (0/S)
dialogues.text: I'm going to sulk. I'm going to sit here and sulk until you get back.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: (pleased) Good. Okay my sausage, I love you. Rupert makes a face at his friend’s sentimentality. Clift beams.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you were going anywhere?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: I’m not. I’m going to surprise her. It’s our anniversary. She’s forgotten, of course. What’s the symbol of your first anniversary? I should get something. Is it cotton or paper?

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: First anniversary? I thought you two had been married for donkey’s years?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: We've been friends for donkey’s years. Best friends. She was always crying on my shoulder about somebody - until I persuaded her to settle for my shoulder. Stroke of genius. {he calls through the partition into the next office) Moose, you there? First anniversary - is that cotton? A man walks into the office, his code name is MOOSE. We k as CARAVAGGIO. He has fewer grey hairs, AND THUMBS.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Is what cotton? 58

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: First wedding anniversary.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Your first anniversary is Paper. EXT. CAIRO STREET, 0/S SHEPHEARD'’S HOTEL. DAY The approach to the Shepheard’s Hotel. Geoffrey Clifton i TAXI, champagne between his knees. The car ahead of them SCREECHES TO A HALT as a WOMAN hurr across the street. The driver honks his horn angrily. The puts up a hand in apology as she skips across the street another taxi. IT’S KATHARINE - she asks the driver for an address in the old town. Geoffrey, at first excited, is troubled by Katharine’s expression. Then he sees her skip and his whole being punctures. Katharine’s cab roars off. His own car jerks forward.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Stop! Stop here.

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: Please? Yessir. Geoffrey sits in the cab. Fifty yards short of the hotel. world rushes by.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ALMASY'S ROOMS. LATE DAY
dialogues.text: Katharine is in bed. Almasy has just put A RECORD on. It' folk song heard at the beginning of the film. He slips ba under the covers. Their clothes are scattered around the He lies over a happy Katharine. She listens.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: This is - what is this?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: It’s a folk song.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Arabic?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: No, no, it’s Hungarian. My daijka sang it to me when I was a child in Budapest. 59

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (as they listen) It’s beautiful. What's it about?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (as if interpreting) Szerelem means love...and the story - there’s this Hungarian count, he’s a wanderer, a fool. For years he’s on some kind of a quest, for - who knows what? And then one day he falls under the spell of a mysterious English woman - a harpy - who beats him and hits him and he becomes her slave and sews her clothes and worships the hem of her- Katharine had thought for a few seconds he was serious, t she catches on and starts to beat him.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (laughing) Ouch! See - you’re always beating me...!

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You bastard, I was believing you! You should be my slave. They embrace, he lies over her, considering her naked bac

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I claim this shoulder blade - no, wait - I want - turn over - I want this! He turns her over, kisses her throat, then traces the hol indentation.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: This piace, I love this place, what’s it called - this is mine! (Katharine doesn’t know) I’m going to ask the King permission to call it the Almasy Bosphorous. 60

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (teasing) I thought we were against ownership? (Almasy acknowledges the irony) I can stay tonight. The luxury of this makes them both sad. The duplicity. Al rolls away onto his back.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Madox knows, I think. He keeps talking about Anna Karenina. I think it’s his idea of a man-to-man chat. It’s my idea of a man-to-man chat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: This is a different world - is what I tell myself. A different life. And here I am a different wife.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Yes. Here you are a different wife. INT. CAB, CAIRO STREET, 0/S SHEPHEARD’S HOTEL. NIGHT The CAB DRIVER is asleep. In the back of the car Geoffrey opened the champagne. He lets it overflow, then takes a s He fusses with the tissue paper from the bottle, unravell it, revealing a chain of hearts.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALMASY'S HOUSE, OLD CAIRO. DAWN
dialogues.text: Almasy and Katharine wander out of his building and into early morning streets, hand in hand.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SPICE MARKET, CAIRO. DAWN
dialogues.text: The MORNING PRAYERS rise out from the city’s three Minare They stop at a stall, which is just preparing to open for day. Katharine examines the collection of silver thimbles picks one up.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: These are darling. What are they, thimbles? . 61

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s full of saffron, just in case you think I’m giving it to you to encourage your sewing. He points it out to the merchant who gives him a price. W comment, Almasy produces the money and, beaming, hands th thimble to Katharine.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I don’t care to bargain.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: That day, had you followed me to the market?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (leving him, but frightened) Shall we be all right?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. (shrugs) Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAIRO STREET. DAWN
dialogues.text: Katharine takes leave of Almasy on the street corner away the hotel entrance. They don’t kiss. There’s a moment whe their hands brush, linger, then she leaves him at the top the stairs and disappears. INT. CAB, CAIRO STREET, 0/S SHEPHEARD’S HOTEL. DAY Geoffrey, unshaven, slumped in the taxi, watches as Katha crosses the street and heads towards the hotel. His expre is terrible, trying to smile, his face collapsed.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. MORNING
dialogues.text: “Cheek to Cheek” leaks into the room from a GRAMOPHONE th Caravaggio stands over proudly. The Patient opens his eye confused, dislocated - stares blankly at Caravaggio.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: (grinning) Thought you'd never wake up! 62

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: What? Hana comes in, sleepily, frowns at the gramophone.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Where did you find that?

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: I liberated it.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I think that’s called looting.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: (relaxed) No one should own music. The real question is, who wrote the song?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Irving Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: For?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Top Hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a song you don’t know?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (speaking for him) No. He sings all the time. She goes over to The Patient and kisses him gently.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Good morning. (of his singing) Did you know that? You’re always singing.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I‘ve been told before.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Kip’s another one. She goes to the window, looks over to where the tents are pitched, sees Hardy shaving and Kip in the process of was his hair, his turban hanging like a ribbon between two tr dry. He’s perched a bowl and is dipping his long coal-bla 63

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hair into it. As Hana watches Kip, Caravaggio changes the record. The Patient identifies it immediately.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: “Wang Wang Blues.”

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: You‘re incredible! EXT. MONASTERY GARDEN. MORNING. Hana walks towards the tent, and passes Hardy. She’s carr small cup, which she’s a little furtive about. He’s carry whole armada of OIL LIGHTS. He nods upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Good morning, miss.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Hello. You saved my life. I haven't forgotten. (Hardy waves that away) I thought you were very very tall. You seemed so big and - a giant! - and I felt like a child who can’t keep her balance.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (does a little mime) A toddler.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (smiles) A toddler. She goes on outside, and tentatively approaches Kip, who’ still working at his hair.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: My hair was long. At some point. I’ve forgotten what a nuisance it is to wash. He continues to wash. She holds up the cup of oil.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Try this. I found a great jar of it. Olive oil.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Thank you. She stands for a second, just wanting to be close, then s walks away. Kip examines the oil, calls after her. 64

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Is this for my hair?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (turning, smiling) Yes, for your hair. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. EVENING. Caravaggio is with The Patient. They sit lost in the jazz they're listening to. The Patient regards Caravaggio.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: There was a general who wore a patch over a perfectly good eye. The men fought harder for him. Sometimes I think I could get up and dance. Caravaggio doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: What’s under your mittens? (still nothing from Caravaggio) What’s under your mittens? Caravaggio stands, goes to him, removing his mittens. INT. BRITISH HEADQUARTERS, TOBRUK, JUNE 1942. DAY. Caravaggio, thumbs intact and wearing a crumpled linen su walks through the mangled corridors of British HQ. Smoke rising from buildings, the ominous scream of Stuka dive-b in the distance as the harbour is pounded, the steady thu explosions. TOBRUK IS UNDER SIEGE. BHQ is a place in the of dismantling itself. SECRETARIES are visiting braziers by ARAB BOYS who stoke the fires as boxes of restricted p are fed into them. ASHES hover in the air. INT. BHQ. TOBRUK DAY. Caravaggio walks through a large room crowded with desks. one of them, a young woman, AICHA, frowning at the chaos the shelling, approaches him. AICHA is Caravaggio’s somet lover.

dialogues.speaker: AICHA
dialogues.text: He's waiting for you. I‘11 see you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR OF BRITISH HEADQUARTERS, TOBRUK. DAY
dialogues.text: Fenelon-Barnes and Caravaggio make their way down the sta and to the entrance. Aicha passes them on the stairs, loo anxiously at Caravaggio. 65

dialogues.speaker: FENELON-BARNES
dialogues.text: Look, Moose, we need you to stay in Tobruk. I know it’s a bit of a short straw but the thinking is we'll be back - I mean, we will, we will be back - but we need eyes and ears on the ground. Jerry's got our maps, you know. Swine. Before the war we helped them run about the desert making maps - and now they’re getting spies into Cairo using our maps, they'11 get Rommel into Cairo using our maps. The whole of the desert’s like a bloody bus route and we gave it to them. Any foreigner who turned up - “Welcome to the Royal Geographic, take our maps.” Old Madox went mad, you know - did you know Peter Madox? - magnificent explorer - after he found out he'd been betrayed by Almasy, his best friend. Absolutely destroyed the poor sod. I’d love to get that bastard Almasy. Settle the score.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOBRUK. DAY
dialogues.text: The Germans invade Tobruk. They drop to the ground in clu of parachutes. The harbour rocks with explosions.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOBRUK DOCKSIDE. DAY
dialogues.text: A GERMAN TROOP CARRIER rumbles forward passing a line of BEDRAGGLED BRITISH POWS as they’re marched along the side the harbour;passing a dock in which the mangled carcasses boats send up plumes of ugly smoke.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOBRUK SQUARE. DAY
dialogues.text: A crowd of Tobruk CIVILIANS - French and Italians among t MOSTLY ARAB FACES. Their papers are being thoroughly chec officers sitting at open desks. In a line, wearing his sh suit, is CARAVAGGIO. AN ARAB WOMAN in front of him is arg over the identity of her ominous CAUCASIAN-LOOKING BABY. INTERPRETER mediates. The OFFICER doesn’t believe the wom She's getting frantic at the possibility of losing her ch Suddenly there’s a disturbance as a WOMAN is dragged alon line by her hair. She's bloodied, and has been tortured, it’s hard to recognize her as the pretty AICHA. She is fo to consider some horrified members of the line, shakes he 66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: head, moans, falls to her feet. Caravaggio doesn’t look, straight ahead. An officer watches him as he turns briefl helplessly out of concern for her. Their eyes catch for a instant and the officer sees it. Caravaggio slowly walks away from the line. A soldier sho halt, the crowd ducks for cover. Caravaggio puts up his a surrender.

dialogues.speaker: INT. INTERROGATION ROOM, TOBRUK. DAY
dialogues.text: Caravaggio is slumped at a table, HIS HANDS MANACLED TO I THICK WOODEN LEGS. There’s A TELEPHONE at another table i corner of the room attended by a CLERK with A STENOGRAPHE working next to him. The room has stone walls which appea damp, and no windows. SOLDIERS stand guard at the door. I horrible room. Caravaggio is trying to sleep, he’s unshav pasty-looking. His interrogator, MULLER, seems incredibly and aggravated. He approaches the table carrying a collec of photographs which he lays down on the table in front o Caravaggio.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: David Caravaggio.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (of the photographs) This was taken in Cairo at British Headquarters - July +41. And so was this - August *41. And this - February ‘42.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: It’s possible. I was buying or selling something. I've been to Cairo many times.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: You are a Canadian spy working for the Allies. Code name Moose. THE PHONE rings again, is answered. The Clerk calls to Mu who gets up, irritably. Caravaggio addresses the room.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Could you get me a doctor? I'm sick, I’m leaking blood. Nobody responds. Muller is irascible on the phone, checki watch, negotiating time. The call finishes. 67

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: (in German) He’s asking for a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (to Caravaggio) You want a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: I've been asking for weeks, months, I don’t know -

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: We don't have a doctor, but we do have a nurse.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: (taken aback) A nurse? Well, sure, great. A nurse would be great. A nurse? Great. Muller nods at the Clerk, who instantly gets up. Just the telephone rings again. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (in German) Leave it and get the nurse! The Clerk exits.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (turns to Caravaggio) Look - give me something. A name. A code. So we can all get out of this room. (wiping his face) I’m sick of this heat. It’s too hot.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: I slept with a girl. I’ve got a wife in Tripoli. A girl comes up and points at you, you only see trouble. The NURSE comes in. She is Arab, unbearably young, pure. head is covered.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: I‘11 tell you what I’m going to do. This is your nurse, by the way. She’s Moslem, so she’1ll understand all of this. What’s the punishment for adultery? Let’s leave it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MULLER (cont ‘d) at that. You‘re married and you were fucking another woman, so that’s - is it the hands that are cut off? Or is that for stealing? Does anyone know? There’s a silence. Muller turns to Caravaggio.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Well, you must know. You were brought up in Libya, yes?

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Don’t cut me.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Or was it Toronto? Now the phone starts again. The CLERK picks it up, there’ terse exchange, he puts the receiver on the desk, waits f moment to interrupt Muller.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Ten fingers. How about this? You give me a name for every finger - doesn’t matter who. I get something, you keep something. I'm trying to be reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: (ashen) Don’t cut me. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (pauses, suddenly puzzled) Are thumbs fingers? {in GERMAN to the others) Is a thumb a finger? No response. Muller opens his palms to Caravaggio.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: I get no help from these people. Muller slams down the telephone receiver. An AIR RAID SIR going off somewhere, and now the faint sound of explosion also discernable, but all muffled in this room along with steady tap-tap of the STENOGRAPHER. At ‘that moment, Mull suddenly becomes aware of what is happening. He turns on Stenographer. 69

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (in German) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: STENOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: (awkward, in German) The Geneva Convention. I’m - Muller peremptorily rips out the paper, throws it on the

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: The Geneva Convention! Ach!

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Hey - Come on! You can’t do that! DURING THIS Muller's gone to the table, pulled out a draw and produced A CUT-THROAT RAZOR. He hands it to the Nurse makes a line across his own left thumb and jerks his head towards Caravaggio. The Nurse is extremely reluctant. Mul claps his hands, pushes her towards Caravaggio.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Go! Hey! Gol Caravaggio is in terror.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: I'll give you names. I’1l give you names. What names did you say? I’ve forgotten the names. Tell me the names and I’1l agree. The guards come away from the door and press down on Caravaggio’s shoulders to prevent him from moving. The Nu grim-faced, approaches, kneels at the table, takes the bl from Muller, takes gentle hold of Caravaggio’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: {as she prepares to cut) Please - please - oh please - oh please - I promise. What name did you say? I knew them!

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (jabbing at the Nurse) Come on! And then Caravaggio SCREAMS AND SCREAMS. The AIR RAID is continuing outside, the PHONE IS RINGING. Muller watches Caravaggio is mutilated, his cries continuing, his whimpe horrible. 70  INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. NIGHT. Caravaggio, his hands revealed, thumbless, advances on Th Patient, his cries still ringing in the room.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: {The man who took my thumbs, I found him eventually - I killed him. The man who took my photograph, I found him too - that took me a year. He’s dead. Another man helped get that man across the desert to Cairo. I’ve been leoking for him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIBRARY OF THE DEPARTMENT OF EGYPTOLOGY. DAY
dialogues.text: Madox and Almasy are camped in one corner of THE LIBRARY, hunched over their maps and papers and journals and clash furiously over the site of the next part of the expeditio

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: (pushing away his charts) You can’t get through there.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I was looking again at Bell's maps. If we can find a way to cross the wadi we can drive straight up into Cairo... (he points at a map) - and this whole spur is a real possibility...

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: So - on Thursday you don’t trust Bell’s map - “Bell was a fool, Bell couldn’t draw a map” - but on Friday he’s suddenly infallible? Almasy is surprised by Madox’s anger.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: And where are the Expedition Maps?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: In my room.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: Those maps belong to His Majesty’s Government. They shouldn't be left lying 71

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADOX (cont‘d) around for any Tom, Dick or Harry to have sight of.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: What on earth's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: Don’t be so bloody naive. You know there’s a war breaking out. (he tosses a slip of paper onto the map, recites its message) This arrived this morning. By order of the British Government - all International Expeditions to be aborted by May 1939.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAIRO SOUK. LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Almasy and Madox walk through the souk, the bars filling the stalls are closing. Both of them are sombre.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: What do they care about our maps?

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: What do we find in the desert? Arrowheads, spears. In a war, if you own the desert, you own North Africa.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (contemptuous ) Own the desert. Almasy hesitates at a junction, clearly about to take his of Madox.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Madox - that place, that place at the base of a woman’s throat? You know, the hollow, here ~- does it have an official name? Madox looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: For God's sake, man - pull yourself together. 72

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OPEN-AIR CINEMA is just beginning its evening program PATHE NEWS BEGINS and we date the event to April 1939. St of imminent war jostle with images of Merrie England. Vil greens, sporting victories, record sunshine on the Isle o Wight. Alone among the necking couples - mostly soldiers their Egyptian girlfriends - sits Katharine. She’s waitin Almasy. Katharine is wretched. She sits, head down, hardl watching the screen, marooned in her despair about duplic sordid assignations. Almasy arrives, slides in beside Katharine, his shadow momentarily large across the screen.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Sorry. They watch the screen. Katharine is weeping. Almasy doesn understand. He puts his arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I ean't do this, I can’t do this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OPEN-AIR CINEMA, CAIRO. EVENING
dialogues.text: LATER and Katharine and Almasy sit stiffly under the blea while the main feature - a Busby Berkeley revue - plays i background. Finally, Katharine gets up.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I‘d better go now. Say goodbye here.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I'm not agreeing. Don’t think I’m agreeing, because I’m not. They stand, awkward. Katharine rehearses her position.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Any minute now, he’1l find out, we‘ll barge into someone - it will kill him.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Don't go over it again, please. He takes her hands, lays his cheeks into them. She pulls hand away as she makes for the exit. He calls after her. 73

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Katharine - He looks toward her, his smile awful.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I just wanted you to know. I’m not missing you yet. She nods, can’t find this funny.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You will. You will. She turns sharply from him and BANGS her head against the bleacher support, staggers at the shock of it, then hurri away.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The patient's stertorous breathing, each intake accompani a small noise, a note, suddenly stops. Then it steadies a He appears to be alone. Caravaggio lies under his bed, sm a vigil. INT. AMBASSADOR’S RESIDENCE, CAIRO, 1939. NIGHT Last seen at the troops’ Christmas party, the INNER COURT has been transformed into an elegant outdoor banquet, wit small band providing entertainment. The Aimasy/Madox team assembled for A FAREWELL DINNER. They are waiting for Alm arrive, his seat conspicuously empty. He is very late. An he’s there, dangerously drunk, terribly dashing. He pract dances to his chair which he drags violently away from it position opposite Katharine. He bows to Lady Hampton.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I believe I’m rather late.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: (ignoring the drama of this entrance) Good, we're all here? A toast, to the International Sand Club - may it soon resurface.

dialogues.speaker: THE OTHERS
dialogues.text: The International Sand Club!

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (raising his glass) The International Sand Club! Misfits, buggers, fascists, and fools. God bless us, everyone. 74

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others drink, trying to ignore his mood.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Oops! Mustn’t say International. Dirty word. Filthy word. His Majesty! Die Fuhrer! Il Duce!

dialogues.speaker: CLIFTON
dialogues.text: Sorry, what’s your point?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (not responding) And the people here don’t want us. You must be joking. The Egyptians are desperate to get rid of the Colonials... (to an embarrassed Fouad) Isn't that right, Fouad? Some of their best people down on their hands and knees begging to be spared a knighthood... (to his host, Sir Hampton) Isn‘t that right? Isn’t that right, Sir Ronnie? Ronnie Hampton shrugs. They’re all very uncomfortable. Al turns to Clifton.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: What’s my point? (standing up) Oh! I’ve invented a new dance ~ anybody up for it - it’s called - it’s called - the Bosphorus Bug. Madox? Bermann? You'll dance with me... D’Ag? Come on D’Aggers. D’‘ AGOSTINO Let’s eat first. Sit down. The Band is now playing ‘Manhattan’ Almasy, without missi beat, begins to sing, replacing the words with alternativ knows. He lurches around. Katharine can’t look at him.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: ‘4+. We'll bathe at Brighton, the fish you'll frighten when you're in - your bathing suit so thin, will make the shellfish grin, fin to fin.’ They‘re playing it far too 75

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMASY (cont‘d) slowly, but these were the words, actually, before they were cleaned up. Might be a song for you, Mrs. Clif - Madox gets up and pulls Almasy into his chair, taking cha

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: (whispering sharply) Look, either shut up, or go home. You're completely plastered! Now sit down.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (loudly) Absolutely right, shut up, shut up. Sorry. I'm so sorry. I can’t think what came over me. Lashings of apologies — all round. EXT. AMBASSADOR’S RESIDENCE. NIGHT Later, and now MOST OF THE GROUP ARE DANCING. We see Kath dancing with Rupert Douglas, enjoying herself. Bermann is and even Madox - jogging and grinning foolishly. Clifton at Katharine who, as the dance ends, excuses herself to g the cloakroom. Almasy hovers in the shadows, unseen.

dialogues.speaker: INT. AMBASSADOR'S RESIDENCE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Katharine comes along the familiar warren of rooms and corridors and is suddenly confronted by Almasy, tortured out of control.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Why were you holding his collar?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (mimicking her inflection) What? That boy, that little boy, you were holding his collar, you were gripping his collar, what for? Is he next? You going to drag him into ur little room? Where is it? Is this it?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Don’t do this. 76

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (pressing her against the wall) I’ve watched you - I've watched you at garden parties, on verandahs, at the Races - how can you stand there? How can you ever smile? As if your life hadn't capsized?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You know why. You know why. He tries to hold her. She resists. They're both in tormen

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Dance with me.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (tracing her shoulder blade) Dance with me. I want to touch you. I want the things which are mine. Which belong to me.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (sobbing) Do you think you’re the only one who feels anything? Is that what you think? INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. NIGHT Hana sits with the patient. His eyes are full of tears. H opens them, sees her watching over him. He's embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Why don’t you go? Get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Would you like me to? He nods. She gets up from her sewing, then leaves.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MONASTERY, LANDING AND STAIRS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Hana leaves the room, then turns and sees a tiny lamp on floor. It’s made from a snail shell filled with oil. She to it curiously, then sees & second lamp half-way down th stairs, then a third further down. She smiles in the ligh then follows the trail. 77

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the cloisters the trail of shell lamps continues, like cat's eyes. As they reach the hopscotch chalk marks, they outline the squares. Hana hopscotches and then follows th lights, disappearing around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MONASTERY STABLES. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Hana comes through into the stables. The lamps lead her, they stop. She peers into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: KIP, (0/5)
dialogues.text: Hana She turns to the voice. He steps out of the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (happy) Kip. And he goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AREZZO. DUSK
dialogues.text: Kip, Hana clinging onto him, steers the motorbike in the deserted PIAZZA. They dismount and walk up to the doors o CHURCH.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHURCH. DUSK
dialogues.text: They enter the Church. It’s in almost total darkness. Kip circles Hana with the rope, MAKING A SLING across her wai shoulder. He lights a small flare and hands it to her bef disappearing into the gloom. Hana stands holding the flare. Kip runs up a hill of sandbags, right up into the rafters collects the other end of the rope which is attached to H Holding on to it, he just STEPS OFF INTO THE DARKNESS. SIMULTANEOUSLY HANA IS SWUNG UP INTO THE AIR, her startle echoing around the Church. Kip touches ground, while Hana swings through space, coming to rest about three feet fro FRESCOED WALLS, painted by Piero Della Francesca. Hana’s makes a halo around her head. Now Kip, on the ground, still holding the rope, walks for and causes Hana to SWING to the right. She lets out a gid laugh, exhilarated and nervous, and she flies, illuminati en passant - faces, bodies, angels. Kip guides the rope a they were making love, which in a way they are. 78

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hana arrives, hovering, in front of THE QUEEN OF SHEBA TA TO SOLOMON. She’s overwhelmed. She reaches out to touch t giant neck of the sad Queen. INT. KIP’S TENT. NIGET Hana lies over Kip in the stable, a naked white body plai into a brown one.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: If one night I didn’t come to see you, what would you do?

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: I try not to expect you.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Yes, but if it got late and T hadn‘t shown up?

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Then I’d think there must be a reason.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: You wouldn't come to find me? (Kip shrugs) That makes me never want to come here. (Kip still won’t respond) Then I tell myself he spends all day searching, in the night he wants to be found. Then Kip turns, rolling over to face her.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: I do. I do want you to find me. I do want to be found. I do.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE MONASTERY STABLES. EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Hardy knocks cautiously on the door of the stables. Event Hana opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Ah, I was looking for Lieutenant Singh.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: He’s sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Only we've got to go to work. 79

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I‘ll tell him. What is it? Is it a mine?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: It's a bomb. Up by the Viaduct. She closes the door, then reappears.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Does he have to go?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Pardon me?

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: What if you couldn’t find him...? (Hardy's bewildered) Sergeant, not today, please. Not this morning. Kip comes to the door, winding his turban.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: What’s happening? Am I needed?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I’m afraid so, sir. Kip hurries to his tent. Hana follows him.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Don’t go. I’m frightened.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: This is what I do. I do this every day.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A VIADUCT NORTH OF THE MONASTERY. DAY
dialogues.text: Kip is lowered by a pulley into the shaft the sappers hav around the bomb. Hardy supervises. The bomb’s huge - 2,00 pounds - and protrudes ostrich-like from the pit, its nos into a pool of sludge at the base of the viaduct. Kip steps off and sinks knee-deep in mud, grunting in dis Warily, he touches his huge opponent, feeling the conditi the case. He wipes the metal. Reveals a serial number, ca out to Hardy, who’s perched on the bank. 80

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Serial number - KK-IP2600. Kip stares at the number. A bomb with his name on it.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (noting it down) KK-IP2600 Sir! I‘11, get the oxygen.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD APPROACHING VIADUCT. DAY
dialogues.text: Hana cycles along on Caravaggio’s bicycle. A TANK comes r up behind her, then a second and third, loaded up with pe citizens and soldiers, and children - waving flags and gesticulating. She lets the metal circus go by.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOMB SHAFT. DAY
dialogues.text: Back in the shaft, Kip works away, his fingers shaking wi cold from the oxygen he’s using to freeze the fuse. Sudde there’s a VIOLENT TREMOR. The ground is SHUDDERING, and K tools are falling into the sludge.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Hardy! What‘s happening?!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VIADUCT. DAY
dialogues.text: The TANKS are rumbling towards the Viaduct. HORNS start sounding. Hardy, below, bellows at his men above for explanation.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Corporal !?

dialogues.speaker: DADE
dialogues.text: (leaning over the parapet of the viaduct) Tanks, sir. Don’t know what it's about.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Stop them!

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Hardy!

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: What is this - a bloody carnival? Stop them!

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: The fuse has snapped! 81

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Sappers run across the bridge towards the oncoming procession. They wave their orange flags, the tanks wave with their flags - Stars and Stripes, Union Jacks. Now SH are ringing out. In the shaft, oblivious, Kip slides out under the bomb, the oxygen spurting everywhere, all over clothes, hissing on the surface of the water. Hardy bends the shaft, heedless of his own safety.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You've got to cut, sir, that frost won’t last.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Go away.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: This is making me incredibly angry.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I know, sir. Kip rubs his hands to warm them up, locates his needle pl and slips them through the tiny gap. His hand touches the casing and the freeze BURNS his hand. He jerks back, DROP THE PLIERS into the watery sludge, cursing. Above them the tanks are rumbling over the bridge, sendin drizzles of dust onto them from the fragile structure. Th cheering continues, oblivious to the crisis below. Now Kip‘s on his hands and knees in the sludge, trying frantically to find the pliers. Hardy looks at his watch, can't help. The seconds run out as Kip groveis in the mud

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Can you feel them? Then, suddenly Kip emerges with the pliers, soaked, shudd He doesn’t know where to cut.

dialogues.speaker: BARDY
dialogues.text: Cut it sir, you‘’ve got to cut itl He goes straight to an exposed loop, no finesse, and cuts There's a snip. Then nothing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VIADUCT. DAY
dialogues.text: Kip and Hardy emerge from their ordeal to join what appea be a party. There are wine bottles and embraces. They’re bewildered. 82

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Get a blanket! (not getting attention) Spalding - get a blanket for the Lieutenant!

dialogues.speaker: DADE
dialogues.text: It’s over, Sir! It’s over. Jerry's surrendered. (to Kip) Well done, well done, Sir! And now they're all shaking hands and slapping backs, and SOLDIERS FROM THE TANKS are there and the victory celebra begin. Kip’s blank, drained, not taking anything in, as D wraps a blanket around his shoulders. Hana arrives on the bicycle and she and Kip embrace priva amidst the celebrations. A different kind of victory for INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. NIGHT Thunder breaks over the Monastery. Hana suddenly comes to door of the room. She looks mischievous.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: It’s raining. And then she bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MONASTERY CLOISTERS. MORNING
dialogues.text: A whoop precedes THE HEADLONG RUSH OF KIP, HARDY, and CARAVAGGIO as they cart The Patient across. the Cloisters Manic stretcher-bearers. Hana is with them, checking on T Patient who bounces uncomfortably. He is nervous, a littl giddy, but laughing. He tries to say something.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: What's he saying?

dialogues.speaker: BANA
dialogues.text: He’s saying it’s wonderful. The rain buckets down as they circle the pond, Hana’s umb threatening to lift her into the air.

dialogues.speaker: A VICTORY CELEBRATION PARTY.
dialogues.text: The gramophone plays. Kip sits in the window, the shutter the village lit up behind his head, nodding to the music, sucking out of his condensed milk. Elsewhere there is an 83

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bottle of cognac, some wine. The Patient has a beaker of Caravaggio is dancing with Hana.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Kip - come and dance with us.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: (a sly wobble of the head) Later.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. The Patient watches, his head nodding to the music.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A tiny PIAZZA where the Sappers and the Villagers are hav their own, more raucous, Victory Feste. There are accordi there’s dancing, and there’s HARDY, stripped to some exot underpants, clambering up the STATUE OF A FIRST ~ WORLD - SOLDIER IN THE MIDDLE OF THE FOUNTAIN. It's currently spo a German Helmet and Hardy has a British replacement in hi hands. He also has a UNION JACK FLAG between his teeth. H extremely drunk and extremely happy. The rest of the Bomb Squad and the other party-goers roar approval.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Hana and Caravaggio are still dancing. There's a muffled thud in the distance. Kip’s ears prick glances for an instant out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (anxious, of the noise) What was that? She is spinning with Caravaggio. When she comes around ag Kip has gone.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE, ITALY 1945. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Kip’s motorbike skids into the tiny PIAZZA. A MILITARY AMBULANCE IS ALREADY THERE. The shattered foun the sluiced flagstones, shining wet and slick, give some as to what's happened, as do the elderly standing in the shadows, the distressed girls, arm in arm. ONE GIRL, youn 84

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: quite striking, is particularly inconsolable, her grief s out at the doors of the ambulance. SPALDING salutes Kip, who waves his salute away, just wan to know what happened.

dialogues.speaker: SPALDING
dialogues.text: Booby trap. Sergeant Hardy was running up the Union Jack, sir, up off that statue - it just went off, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DADE
dialogues.text: Sergeant Hardy climbed up, sir, just for a lark. Should have been me, it was my idea. Kip goes to the ambulance. Spalding tries to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: SPALDING
dialogues.text: Sir - you don't want to look. Kip steps into the back of the ambulance, bends over both bodies, does look, then comes out, past the weeping girl.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Who‘s that girl?

dialogues.speaker: DADE
dialogues.text: His fiancee, sir.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: (confused) Hardy's?

dialogues.speaker: DADE
dialogues.text: He kept it a bit dark.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE STABLES. LATE DAY
dialogues.text: Hana approaches. Kip is inside the stable, the door latch sits, impassively, still shocked, as Hana tries to make contact.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Kip. Kip. It’s me. I’m 80 sorry about what happened. (no response) Can I talk to you? (no response) Why won’t you talk to me? I don't understand. Let me come in. She kicks at the door in her frustration. Kip doesn’t mov doesn't appear to hear. 85

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Please, Kip, please! Kip doesn’t respond. Hana is at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PATIENT'S ROOM. EVENING
dialogues.text: The Patient listens as Hana comes back into the monastery climbs the stone steps to her room. He doesn’t know what' happening. Feels desperately isolated.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Hana? Hana? INT. HANA’S ROOM. EVENING Later, and Hana sits in her room, despondent, lost in her thoughts. Then she is distracted by conversation in The Patient's room below. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. NIGHT The Patient’s eyes open to see Caravaggio at the morphine

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Hana tells me you’re leaving.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: (preparing the injection) There's going to be trials, they want me to interpret, don’t they know I’m allergic to courtrooms? He delivers the injection into The Patient’s arm. The Pat sighs. Caravaggio takes off his jacket. A pistol is stuck his waistband, and he places it ominously on the altar. T Patient sees it.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: So, I come across the Hospital Convoy - (holds up the syringe) - I'm looking for this stuff, and this nurse, Mary, tells me about you and Hana, hiding in some monastery, in - retreat - (he administers his own injection, using his teeth to grip the sleeve) - how you came out of the Desert and you were burned and you didn’t remember your 86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARAVAGGIO (cont’d) name but you knew the words to every song that ever was and you had one possession - a copy of Herodotus - and it was filled with letters and cuttings and then I knew it was you. (he glares at The Patient) I saw you writing in that book. At the Embassy in Cairo, when I had thumbs and you had a face and a name.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: T see. Upstairs, sitting on her bed, Hana listens with increasin concern.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Before you went over to the Germans, before you got Rommel’s spy across the desert and inside British Headquarters. He took some pretty good photographs - I saw mine in that torture room in Tobruk, so - they made an impression.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I had to get back to the desert. I made a promise. The rest meant nothing to me.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: The rest meant nothing to me.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: There was a result to what you did. It wasn’t just another expedition. (holds up hands) It did this. If the British hadn‘t unearthed that photographer, thousands of people could have died.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Thousands of people did die, just different people. 87

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Yes, like Madox?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: You know he shot himself - your best friend? When he found out your were a spy.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: (appalled) No. Madox thought I was a spy? No. No. I was never a spy.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BASE CAMP AT THE CAVE OF SWIMMERS. 1939. DAY
dialogues.text: The Expedition Team is packing up the Base Camp. Madox an Almasy are walking together towards the plateau where FOU AUF, and others work at the cars.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: It’s ghastly, it's like a witch hunt - anybody remotely foreign is suddenly a spy, 50 watch out.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: We didn’t care about countries. Did we? Brits, Arabs, Hungarians, Germans. None of that mattered, did it? It was something finer than that.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Yes. It was.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: When's Clifton picking you up?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Tomorrow afternoon. Don’t worry, I'1l be ready.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: I‘11l leave the plane in Kufra Oasis. So if you need it...hard to know how long one’s talking about. We might all be back in a month or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madox kneels and takes A HANDFUL OF SAND, puts it into hi pocket. Almasy puts out a hand. This is a moment of great emotional weight for them both, conducted as if nothing w happening.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: I have to teach myself not to read too much into everything. Comes of too long having to read so much into hardly anything at all.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Goodbye, my friend. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) May God make safety your companion.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (a tradition) There is no God. {smiles) But I hope someone looks after you. Madox clambers up the hill, then remembers something, jab his throat.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: In case you're still wondering - this is called the suprasternal notch. Almasy nods.

dialogues.speaker: MADOX
dialogues.text: Come and visit us in Dorset. When all this nonsense is over. (then shrugs, thick with feeling) You’11 never come to Dorset. Almasy watches Madox leave. INT. PATIENT’S ROOM. DAY The Patient is still digesting the news of Madox’s suicid Caravaggio is a little surprised at his response.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: You didn’t know Madox killed himself? And you didn't kill the Cliftons?

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: No. No. (now he is overwhelmed by the pain of his memory ) She...she ... (then suddenly he’s clear) Well, maybe I did. Maybe I did. Unseen to either of them Hana listens, full of emotion, a story unfolds.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BASE CAMP AT THE CAVE OF SWIMMERS. 1939. DAY
dialogues.text: Almasy sits on a ridge transferring map information from Herodotus onto a sheet of paper. He looks up at the sound Clifton’s approaching Steerman. It passes fast and horrib close to his head.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT, (0/S)
dialogues.text: I was packing up the Base Camp at the Cave of Swimmers. Clifton had arranged to fly down from Cairo to collect me. He flew like a madman, 80 I didn’t take much notice... Clifton is flying towards the landing strip. From the air possible to make out Almasy scrambling down from the ridg towards where stones indicate a landing area, carrying th of the materials from the Cave of Swimmers.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BASE CAMP AT THE CAVE OF SWIMMERS. DAY
dialogues.text: Almasy watches as the plane drops toward him, shielding h eyes against the sun. He stoops to gather up his luggage. Almasy looks up to see the plane swerve, now suddenly HEA STRAIGHT TOWARDS HIM. He's completely vulnerable, nowhere run. He dives at the ground. THE PLANE SMASHES AGAINST AN INVISIBLE RIDGE AND TURNS OVER AND OVER, the wings snappi like twigs as it hurtles past the prostrate Almasy. He ge his feet and starts to run towards the wreckage. A blue line of smoke is uncoiling from the plane, but no Almasy pulls away the debris to find GEOFFREY - SLUMPED, BROKEN, BLOODY. He tries to move him, and in the process reveals, to his ABSOLUTE horror, KATHARINE, STARING GRIML AHEAD, UNABLE TO MOVE. He's frantic. 90

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Katharine! Oh dear God, Katharine - what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (eyes rolling, an incredible weariness) I can’t get out. I can’t move. Almasy starts to pull at the wreck around her. DURING THI

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: ‘A surprise’ he said. (she can hardly talk) Poor Geoffrey. He knew. He must have known all the time. He was shouting - “I love you, Katharine, I love you 80 much.” Is he badly hurt?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I have to get you out. Almasy pute his arms around Katharine to try and pull her clear. She can‘t stand the pain.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Please don’t move me.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I have to get you out.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: It hurts too much.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (can’t bear to hurt her) . I know, darling, I’m sorry. He pulls - hard - the pain from which causes Katharine to then pass out. He lifts her gently into his arms and carr her from the danger of the place.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CAVE OF SWIMMERS. DAY
dialogues.text: Almasy has WRAPPED KATHARINE IN THE SILK FOLDS OF HER PAR and emerges from near the familiar cleft in the rock, struggling with the exertion of the climb as they approac Cave of Swimmers. He has a large water bottle slung aroun neck and a haversack, and is loaded like a pack horse. Katharine opens her eyes. 91

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Why did you hate me?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Don't you know you drove everybody mad?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Shhhh. Don’t talk.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (gasping) You speak so many bloody languages and you never want to talk. They stagger on. He suddenly notices a stain of gold at h neck. It’s saffron, leaking from a silver THIMBLE which h from a black ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (overwhelmed) You're wearing the thimble.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Of course. You idiot. I always wear it. I’ve always worn it. I’ve always loved you. Almasy CRIES as he walks - huge sobs, no words - convulse the pain of it. They approach the Cave.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAVE OF SWIMMERS. DAY
dialogues.text: Almasy comes through in shadows, carrying Katharine, bloc out the light that pours into the entrance of the cave. O inside, he sets her down incredibly gently, makes a bed o blankets and the parachute. He turns on his flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: It’s so cold.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I know. I‘m sorry. I’11 make a fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he makes the fire, the light sends his shadow flitting across the walis. 92

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Did you get Geoffrey from the plane?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (reluctant) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (as he works) Listen to me, Katharine. You’ve broken your ankle and I'm going to have to try and bind it. I think you’ve also broken your wrist - and maybe some ribs, which is why it's hurting you to breathe. I’m going to have to walk to £1 Taj. Although given ail the traffic in the desert these days I’m bound to bump into one army or another. And then I‘1l be back and you'll be fine. The fire is lit and he comes over to her, kneels beside h

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Do you promise? I wouldn't want to die here. I don’t want to die in the desert. I’ve always had rather an elaborate funeral in mind, with particular hymns. Very English. And I know exactly where I want to be buried. In our garden. Where I grew up. With a view of the sea. So promise me you’11 come back for me.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I promise I’11 come back. I promise I'll never leave you. Now, you have plenty of water and food. He kisses her tenderly. Pulls out his HERODOTUS and lays beside her. Then he puts down the FLASHLIGHT. 93

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: And a good read. (of the flashlight battery) Don't waste this.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Thank you. (clouds over) Will you bury Geoffrey? I know he’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Katharine.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I know. He's tearing strips from the parachute with his knife.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Every night I cut out my heart but in the morning it was full again. He leans over her, desperately worried for her. She smile

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Darling. My darling.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DESERT. DAWN
dialogues.text: Almasy’s walking. He’s singing to keep awake. Darktown Strutter’s Ball. - ’I'11 be down to get you in the taxi, honey...’

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DESERT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Almasy trudges on.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT, (0/S)
dialogues.text: I stopped at noon and at twilight. ‘Three days there’, I told her, ‘then three hours back by car. Don't go anywhere. I’1l be back. I‘1l be back’.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DESERT. DUSK
dialogues.text: Almasy continues, his journey taking him through miles of undulating dunes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. EL TAJ. DAY
dialogues.text: Finally Almasy arrives at the outskirts of El Taj. He sta 94

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: towards this ancient Trading Post. A Brtish Sentry watche approach with interest. EXT. SQUARE AT EL TAJ. DAY. The Sentry, a CORPORAL, brings Almasy into a square. A yo OFFICER sits at a table in the shadows of his office. His CAR is parked in the shade.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Good morning! (the Corporal has a water bottle, hands it to Almasy) So, golly, where have you come from?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (gulping the water, trying to summon his thoughts) There’s been an accident. I need a doctor - to come with me. And I need to borrow this ear. I’1l pay, of course, and I need, I need morphine and -

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: May I see your papers, sir?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: If I could just see some form of identification?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (brain racing) I’m sorry, I’m not making sense, forgive me, I‘ve been walking, I’ve - there’s a woman badly injured at Gilf Kebir, in the Cave of Swimmers. I am a member of the Royal Geographical Society.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Right. Now, if I could just take your name.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (trying to control his feelings) Count Laszlo de Almasy. 95

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Officer is writing this down. A glance at his Corpora

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Almasy - would you mind spelling that? What nationality would that be?

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Look, listen to me. A woman is dying - my wife! - is dying. I have been walking for three days! I do not want to spell my name, I want you to give me this car!

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: (writing) I understand you are agitated - perhaps if you’d like to sit down I could radio back to

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (snapping) No! No! Don’t radio anybody, just, just give me the fucking car! Almasy sets on the Officer, hauling him by the lapels, bu immediately loses his balance. As he stumbles up he gets stock of the Corporal's RIFLE Across his head, KNOCKING H THE GROUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katharine has been writing in the Herodotus. The torchlig FLICKERS as it illuminates some words - ‘Drag myself outs is legible, then ‘We die, we die’ - She shakes the torch. FLICKERS again. Then goes out. Absolute BLACKNESS. The so her trembling breath, of her terror.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. EL TAJ STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Almasy, head pounding, is in the back of the jeep, chaine . the tailgate. He’s desperate. The Corporal is driving.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: (shouting, hoarse) Stop the car. Please. A woman is dying!

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: Listen, Fritz, if I have to listen to another word from you I'm going to give you a fucking good hiding. 96

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Fritz? What are you talking about? Fritz?

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: That’s your name innit? Count Fucking Arsehole Von Bismarck? What’s that supposed to be then, Irish? Almasy, berserk, starts to yank at his chains, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Please! You have to listen! please, listen to me - Katharine! Katharine!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A TRAIN, THE DESERT. DUSK
dialogues.text: A TRAIN scuttles through the desert.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN, THE DESERT. DUSK
dialogues.text: Almasy is HANDCUFFED to the metal grille of the goods compartment. He’s lying down among a bunch of other priso and their little bundles of possessions in this makeshift - some Arabs, some Italians. AA SERGEANT pushes a lavatory-bound prisoner along the co leaving behind A YOUNG PRIVATE who sits on a packing case a rifle across his lap, reading a Penguin edition of Gull Travels. Almasy is in complete despair to be on the train tries to move, but he’s locked tight to the grille. He ra the cuffs against the metal.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. (the Soldier looks up) I also need to use the lavatory.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: You'll have to wait.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: It’s urgent.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (calls up the corridor) Sarge! Jerry wants to use the lav - says it’s urgent.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Where are we going, please? 97

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Up North, to the coast. Benghazi. Soon be there. Get you a boat back home. Almasy can’t bear this news. fhe SERGEANT returns, consid the request.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Go on then - you take him. I’ve been up and down this bloody train all day.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN CORRIDOR, THE DESERT. DAY
dialogues.text: The Soldier pushes Almasy along the corridor. They arrive outside the lavatory. The Soldier is distracted for a spl second. Enough for Almasy to ELBOW HIM savagely in the st winding him, before battering his with his fists. He wrap cuffs around the Soldier’s neck and - yanking them togeth twisting - proceeds to strangle the young soldier.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN, THE DESERT. EVENING
dialogues.text: Almasy clambers over the guardrail and leaps off, tumblin the desert sunset.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RAILWAY TRACK, THE DESERT. EVENING
dialogues.text: Almasy, silhouetted against the evening sky, hobbles back the track, THREE HUNDRED MILES AWAY from the dying Kathar Clifton, no way now of saving her. He is a tiny speck in vast desert. His heart broken. He sinks to his knees in despair. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. NIGHT The Patient is exhausted. He has said aloud what has tort him. His failure to save Katharine. He looks at Caravaggi

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: So yes. She died because of me. Because I loved her. Because I had the wrong name.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: And you never got back to the cave?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. KUFRA OASIS. DAY
dialogues.text: Almasy is uncovering the tarpaulin which has been protect Madox’s TIGER MOTH. Around him are German soldiers, two o are bringing cans of gasoline towards the plane. 98

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT, (0/S)
dialogues.text: I did get back. I kept my promise. I was assisted by the Germans. I had our expedition maps. And after the British made me their enemy, I gave their enemy our maps. Almasy carries a mapcase and hands it over to the German officer, who salutes him and walks toward his car. Almasy to the plane, rips off a sign Madox has pinned to a wing. reads SEE YOU IN DORSET.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT, (0/S)
dialogues.text: So I got back to the desert and to Katharine in Madox‘s English plane with German gasoline. When I arrived in Italy, on my medical chart, they wrote ‘English Patient’ Isn’t that funny, after all that I became English.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Caravaggio is looking out the window, his mind racing, hi resolve evaporating.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: You get to the morning and the poison leaks away, doesn’t it? Black nights. I thought I would kill you.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: You can’t kill me. I died years ago.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: No, I can’t kill you now. Above them, in her room, Hana stands, having heard it all whole story; the whole puzzle finally in place.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MONASTERY. APPROACHING DAWN
dialogues.text: Kip has pulled out all of Hardy’s gear. Now he starts on tent, kicking at the pegs, collapsing it. Hana comes out the garden, to join him. She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: We've been posted. North of Florence. 99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he's trying to fold a shirt. Hana takes it from him. folds it.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: I was thinking yesterday - yesterday! - the Patient, and Hardy: they’re everything that’s good about England. I couldn't even say what that was. We didn’t exchange two personal words, and we've been together through some terrible things, some terrible things. {still incredulous) He was engaged to a girl in the village! - I mean - (looks at Hana) ~- and us - he never once... He didn’t ask me if I could spin the ball at cricket or the Kama Sutra or - I don’t even know what I'm talking about.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: You loved him. EXT. (NEAR THE) BASE CAMP AT THE CAVE OF SWIMMERS. 1942. The familiar cleft in the rocks. The Tiger Moth lands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flashlight flickers in the cave. ALMASY APPEARS. KATHARINE’S CORPSE lies where he left her - a ghost on a silk and blankets. The chill of the cave has preserved he could be asleep.

dialogues.speaker: ALMASY
dialogues.text: Katharine. He sobs, whispering to her. He's terribly cold, exhausted slips underneath the covers to be next to her, and closes eyes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. MORNING
dialogues.text: Hana sits with the English Patient - the room shuttered a the morning light. His breathing is noticeably worsening, shudder of a breath, the shallow rise and fall of his che hardly perceptible. Hana frets, touches his wrist, feelin the pulse. 100

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: I’m still here.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: You'd better be.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Don’t depend on it. Will you? That little bit of air, in my lungs, each day gets less and less, which is all right, which is quite all right. I’ve been speaking to Caravaggio, my research assistant. He tells me there’s a ghost in the cloisters. I can join him. Hana is distracted by the sound of Kip’s motorbike. KIP (o/s) (distant) Hana.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: It's the boy.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MONASTERY. DAY
dialogues.text: Kip sits on the motorbike, waiting for Hana. She goes to stands, fastens the top button of his coat. You feel she just climb on the seat behind him. But she doesn’t. Neith them can think what to say.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I’1l always go back to that church. Look at my painting.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: I‘11 always go back to that church.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: So one day we’1l meet. Be nods, winds up the throttle, and is gone. Hana walks b the Patient's room. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. DAY Hana picks up the hypodermic to prepare his injection. Sh takes a vial. The Patient is watching her. He reaches out pushes two more vials toward her. Their eyes meet, then h shovels another, then all of them. She looks at him. It’s massive lethal dose. 101 i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hana decides, starts to prepare the injection, her eyes f with tears. The Patient nods, smiles, whispers.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Thank you. she holds the loaded syringe up to the light. She's sobbi violently. The Patient’s expression is full of peace.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIENT
dialogues.text: Read to me, will you? Read me to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Hana lies beside The English Patient. She has the Herodot is reading to him from the passage Katharine had written waited for him in the Cave of Swimmers.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: (reading) ‘My darling, I’m waiting for you. How long is a day in the dark? or a week? The fire is gone now and I’m horribly cold.’ The reading continues, but sometimes it's Katharine’s own that’s heard.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: ‘I really ought to drag myself outside - but then there would be the sun. I’m afraid I waste the light on the paintings and on writing these words. We die, we die rich with lovers and tribes, tastes we have swallowed... bodies we have entered and swum up like rivers, fears we have hidden in like this wretched cave...’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almasy smudges Katharine’s pale face with saffron from th thimble. He presses his cheek to hers, smoothes her hair, incredible tenderness.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE, (0/S)
dialogues.text: «..I want all this marked on my body. We are the real countries, not the boundaries drawn on maps with the names of powerful men... 102

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAVE OF SWIMMERS. DAY
dialogues.text: Almasy comes out of the cave, carrying the bundle of Kath in his arms, wrapped in the silks of her parachute. He's shuddering in the throes of his grief, but there’s no sou

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE, (0/5)
dialogues.text: «e. I know you will come and carry me out into the palace of winds...That's all I’ve wanted - to walk in such a place with you, with friends, an earth without maps. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. DAY The Patient is slipping away a8 Hana reads the last of Katharine’s message.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: ‘The lamp’s gone out...and I'm writing in the darkness.‘ She looks up from the book. His eyes roll, his preathing quiets, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LANE OUTSIDE THE MONASTERY GARDEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Caravaggio is at the gate to the Monastery. A TRUCK isp w with him. A family sits in the back of the truck. Caravag stands with a young woman. He shouts into the garden.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Hana!

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PATIENT'S ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Hana lingers in the empty room. fhe mattress stripped bar sign of their stay-

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO, (0/8)
dialogues.text: Hana, come on! Hana! Hana makes to leave, then sees the Herodotus lying on the pedside cabinet, and scoops it up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LANE OUTSIDE MONASTERY GARDEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Hana comes out to the truck, carrying the small bundle of belongings. Caravaggio makes some introductions, beginnin the woman driver, Gioia. She and Caravaggio amile like lo

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: Hana - this is Gioia. Gioia smiles, shakes Hana’s hand. 103

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ft

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: Buon giorno.

dialogues.speaker: CARAVAGGIO
dialogues.text: She‘1l take you as far as Florence.

dialogues.speaker: HANA
dialogues.text: I can get in the back. And she clambers Up, sits down between the children. They exchange some small stiff, shy smiles, and then the truck bounces away. Hana takes one final look at the Monastery disappears around the bend and then turns and confronts t life insisting noisily in the truck.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE COCKPIT
dialogues.text: Almasy, obliterated by goggles and helmet, Katharine ahea him, slumped forward as if sleeping. The plane banks over the dark ravines of the Gilf Kebir, then suddenly, the rocks have gone, giving way to the ear without maps - the desert - stretching out for mile after Almasy, the English Patient, looks down on it.
